#### Dangers of anger, Importance of sense control (Dhamma), Importance of mind control (Shama)
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/KTHudZWO2Ac?t=949
**Verse References:** BG 2.63, BG 2.58, BG 2.60
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "From anger, delusion arises and from delusion, bewilderment of memory. When memory is bewildered, intelligence is lost. And when intelligence is lost, one falls down again into the material pool."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the dangers of anger, leading to delusion and downfall, and emphasizes the importance of both sense control (Dhamma) and mind control (Shama) for spiritual progress, referencing verses from the Bhagavad Gita.

Now when a normal conditioned soul becomes angry, Krishna explains further in the next verse what actually further happens, what does that anger lead to? क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहाथ स्मुर्थि विभ्रमः स्मुर्थि ब्रंशाद् बुद्धि नाश्यो बुद्धि नाश्याद् प्रणश्यति From anger, delusion arises and from delusion, bewilderment of memory. When memory is bewildered, intelligence is lost. And when intelligence is lost, one falls down again into the material pool. So we can see here, Krishna is describing the danger of becoming subjugated by anger. Actually in fact, in the little previous to this, in the 58th verse, Krishna mentions यदा सम्हरते चायम कोर्मों गानेव सर्वशः इन्द्रियाणि इन्द्रियार्थेब्य स्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता One who is able to withdraw his senses from sense objects, as the tortoise draws his limbs within the shell, is to be understood as truly situated in knowledge. So Krishna in the 58th verse, he spoke about Dhamma, controlling the senses. That we all have to control our senses. The senses cannot be freely left to enjoy the sense objects. Now Dhamma entails gross control of the senses. Whereas in the 62nd and 63rd verse, Krishna is speaking actually of Shama, controlling the mind. One is the force of the senses, which impels us to enjoy the sense objects. And the second is the force of the mind. The mind generates certain desires. So if the mind is uncontrolled, then it finally leads to anger, and anger leads to further entanglement in this material world. So, Shama and Dhamma. Dhamma is important, Shama is also important. If we do not control our senses, if Dhamma is not practiced, Krishna says what happens in the 60th verse. He says, यततो ही अप्यकाऊंते ये पुरिशत्सि विपस्चिता इन्द्रियानि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसवं मनः The senses are so strong and impetuous, O Arjuna, that they forcibly carry away the mind even of a man of discrimination who is endeavouring to control them. So even a knowledgeable person, even a person who is a person of discrimination, not an ordinary person, विपस्चिता a person of discrimination, a learned person, an intelligent person, a person who is a ज्यानी even such a person, if his senses are not controlled, what will happen? He will be led to destruction. So, one is दमा another is शमा as we read in the 62nd and 63rd verses, if a person does not practice शमा, he may very well control his senses, but then, if his mind is not controlled, then that will eventually again lead him to destruction.

**Summary:** The speaker explains that while devotees easily practice Dhamma (sense control), Shama (mind control) is often overlooked, and emphasizes the importance of controlling the mind to avoid frustration and maintain interest in Krishna consciousness, highlighting the selfless mood of the Brajavasis who only desire to please Krishna.

So both दमा and शमा are important. Now, in the case of devotees, what happens is दमा is very easily practiced. We follow the four regularity principles strictly, then automatically दमा is practiced. And, but then शमा is something which we consciously, we may miss out in practicing. दमा is very conscious, we will consciously follow. I should avoid onion, garlic, I should not eat meat, I should eat only कृष्ण प्रसादम, very easily we can follow. But शमा is something which many times may miss our attention, that we have to control the mind also. On one level, controlling the mind means we do not allow the mind to dwell on material sense objects. On a higher plane, दमा also means that we cannot allow the mind to think whatever it wants. Sometimes devotees get carried away, that no according to me it should be like this, according to me we should do like this. And then when things don't happen according to the way they are thinking, they become frustrated. And they start thinking, what is all this, I thought I came to devotional service thinking that everything will be nice here, but there are so many problems here, this is not okay, that is not okay. And finally the person will lose his interest in कृष्ण consciousness. So, in the case of devotees, we have to be very careful to practice this शमा, this control of the mind. Sometimes this uncontrolled mind will generate some thoughts which will seem almost like devotional service, it will look like devotional service only. Sometimes devotees think, no I should do something big for कृष्ण and we give them some service, what is this small service you are giving me, I want to do something big, give me some bigger service. So, actually if one has such a mentality, even if one becomes a PR devotee, one will not be able to have permanent residence in the spiritual world. One will have to keep coming back to that. One will have to keep coming back to the material world. Because if we have that desire, I should do something big for कृष्ण. कृष्ण will say, okay, you continue doing that in the material world, you be there and you keep doing big things. Such people will generally become देवताःs. They are pure devotees, but they become देवताःs because they have some desire to serve कृष्ण in some big capacity. So कृष्ण says, okay, remain in the material world and do big things. So, a devotee of the highest order, will generally, will not have this kind of thought. If we look at the ब्रजवासीs, why are they considered the topmost devotees, even above the देवताःs? Why? Because the ब्रजवासीs, they have no desire other than to please कृष्ण. If कृष्ण is pleased by my doing some small service, I will do that small service. I will be happy doing that small service. If कृष्ण wants me to do some big service, then I will do that big service. I am not attached to doing something big or small, I am attached to pleasing कृष्ण.

in whatever service is given to us. #### subtle body, reincarnation, mind-body connection
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/fmJV0kQW6bU?t=29
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Mind, intelligence and false ego transfers us to another body."
**Summary:** The speaker explains the process of reincarnation, emphasizing the role of the subtle body (mind, intelligence, and false ego) in carrying the soul to the next body.

So Krishna tells in the Bhagavad Gita that, within this very life, you can see that we are changing so many bodies. I gave up the body of a baby, got the body of a child, gave up the body of the child, got the body of a youth, gave up the body of the youth, got an old body, got a new body, got an old person's body, and finally when death comes, I will give up this body. So logically speaking, when in this life I have changed so many bodies, but I continue to exist. I didn't cease to exist. Body of the baby finished means I was not finished, I continued, right? So same logic, if you extrapolate, at the time of death, this body will cease to be, I will go on to another body. So when death comes, what happens? We are taken by our subtle body. Mind, intelligence, and false ego transfers us to another body. Actually, that's what has happened to us in this life also. When the body of the baby went away and we got the body of the child, we continue to feel I am the same person. And when we get a youthful body, we continue to feel I am the same person, although the body of the child and the baby is not there. Why? Because the same subtle body is continuing. Same mind, intelligence, and false ego is continuing. That is continuing uninterrupted. So for me, that feeling of I, I am this, doesn't cease. So we don't feel that I am changing the body, because although the gross body is changing, the subtle body is not changing. So the subtle body carries us from the body of the baby to the body of the child to the body of the youth to the body of the old person. Similarly, the subtle body will carry us from this body to the next body. So this cycle of birth and death goes on.

So, in Vedic times, even abduction of a woman was considered so evil that anybody who would do that could be sentenced to death. That was the culture at that time. Today, you know, it's not a major thing. Somebody, even if he forces himself upon a woman, even if he rapes her, maximum the court will give some few years of imprisonment. After that, he is free. And that imprisonment also will come after decades of trial. So many years of trial, then Sessions Court, then the High Court, then the Supreme Court. Practically, by that time, the man who committed the crime will already be on his death bed. What is the use of all this sentencing? So in today's world, the maximum punishment that a man can get for violating a woman's modesty is a few years of imprisonment. That's all. It's not considered all that evil. Whereas, Ravana, just for abducting Sita, he had to give up his life.

#### devotion, attachment, spiritual master, fall down
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Nf67atcHW8M?t=0
**Verse References:** BG 6.41
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "If you were this much attached to Krishna, how much good you might achieve."
**Summary:** HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa narrates the story of Bilvamangal Thakur, a pure devotee who fell from a high spiritual platform due to attachment, and how his spiritual master, through the words of a prostitute, Chintamani, reignited his devotion.

Hare Krishna! Vishwaguru Srila Prabhupada ki Jai! Often, Srila Prabhupada narrated the real-life story of Srila Bilvamangal Thakur. Bilvamangal Thakur was a great pure devotee of Krishna, who is said to have lived around the 8th century, although the exact timelines of his birth are not known. He was a pure devotee who came in the line of Srila Vishnuswami, who is an Acharya of the Rudra Sampradaya. Bilvamangal Thakur is said to have lived for almost 700 years, and he composed many wonderful bhajans on Krishna. His most famous work, of course, is the Krishna Karnamrita, which Sri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu treasured. Bilvamangal Thakur was born into a wealthy Brahmana family, but instead of developing saintly character as a qualified Brahmana, he became attached to a prostitute, Chintamani. He was so attached to the prostitute that he couldn't stay even one day without meeting her. One day, it so happened that Bilvamangal Thakur's father passed away. He was forced to stay back for the funeral rites for his father, but he was still restless to meet Chintamani. You can imagine, Bilvamangal Thakur's father has passed away, and he is still itching to meet Chintamani. That shows how attached he was to the Brahmana family. As soon as the rituals were completed, Bilvamangal Thakur rushed to meet Chintamani the same day because it had already gotten late. By that time, it was already evening and it had started raining heavily. Despite the downpour, Bilvamangal Thakur hurried to meet Chintamani. On the way, he had to cross a river, and when he reached the river, he found that the river was swollen due to the heavy rain, and there was no boat either to take him across the river. Finding no other alternative, what did he do? He jumped into the river, but the current was so fierce, it started sweeping him away. Clutching desperately here and there, he fortunately found something floating in the furious spate of the river waters. Taking it to be a log of wood, he clung on to it for dear life and somehow managed to reach the other bank. With great relief, Billumangal Thakur got out of the water and on some instinct, he turned back and when he turned back, he was horrified to see that what he thought was a log of wood he had been clinging on to was actually a corpse, a dead body. Anyway, he shrugged it off and continued on to Chintamani's house. By now, it was pretty dark and when he reached Chintamani's house, he found that the gate was locked. Since it had become dark and it was raining torrentially, Chintamani thought that Billumangal Thakur would not come today and so, she had locked the main gate and it was pouring because of the sound, the thunder, the lightning, the rain, not being able to attract the attention of anyone inside the house. What happened? Billumangal Thakur became desperate. He tried knocking the gate, he tried doing this, that, but he couldn't capture the attention of anyone within the house. Then, when he was looking around, he luckily found a rope hanging down from the compound wall. So, he was able to get out of the house and he was able to immediately latched on to it, climbed up the wall and jumped over. And after jumping over, when he looked back, he realized that it was not a rope, it was a snake. He had narrowly missed being bitten by the snake to death. Heaving a sigh of relief, he walked up to the house and knocked on the door. Finally, he had reached his destination. What an adventure it had been. Chintamani opened the door, wondering who would have come to her house in the downpour. She was stunned to see Billumangal Thakur standing there. He then narrated to her how he had risked his life not once but twice despite his father's having passed away to come to her doorstep. When Chintamani heard this, she said, if only you had this much attachment to Krishna, your life would have been so glorious. Something like that. Suddenly, somewhere a switch got flipped inside. Billumangal Thakur, without wasting another moment, he turned and left her, never to return. He went on to Sri Vrindavan Dham and the rest, as they say, is history. Srila Prabhupada explains this incident in the book, Path of Perfection, in chapter 8. There, Srila Prabhupada says, in this regard, there is the example of Billumangal Thakur, who in his previous life was elevated almost to premabhakti, the highest platform of devotional service. However, since there is always a chance for a fall down, somehow or other he fell down. In his next life, he was born in a very rich brahmana family in accordance with the principle enunciated in the sixth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, chapter 6, verse 41. Unfortunately, as is often the case with rich boys, he became a prostitute hunter. Yet, it is said that his spiritual master instructed him through his prostitute, saying, oh, you are so attached to this mere flesh and bones. If you were this much attached to Krishna, how much good you might achieve. Immediately, Billumangal Thakur resumed his devotional service. So, you see, what is Srila Prabhupada saying? The words of the prostitute, Chintamani, had such a profound life-transforming effect on Billumangal Thakur. Why? Because it was actually, Billumangal Thakur's Diksha Guru speaking through her. Srila Prabhupada explained this principle in greater detail in this lecture on the Bhagavad Gita, chapter 6, verses 35 through 45, recorded on February 20, 1969 in Los Angeles. Listen to what Srila Prabhupada explained.

### How the GBC changed Deity worship in ISKCON | His Grace Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa
**Speaker:** HG Suvyakta Narasimha Dasa

#### Deity worship, ISKCON history, GBC resolutions, Pancharatra Pradipa
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/k6TE3K_pRk4?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** historical
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "This system was given a stamp of approval and finality by the GBC in the year 1995."
**Summary:** The speaker outlines the GBC's resolutions in 1989 regarding Deity worship, the formation of a research committee, and the publication of the Pancharatra Pradipa in 1995, detailing the procedures for Aarati as described in the manual.

On March 11, 1989, ISKCON Mumbai Group's GBC passed two resolutions regarding Deity worship in ISKCON, Resolutions No. 65 and 66. Resolution No. 65 reads that the GBC body hereby requests the following devotees to research on the basis of Guru, Sadhu and Shastra to help establish ISKCON policies regarding Deity worship – Bhanuswami, Bhakti Vidyapurna Swami, Atma-Tattva, Jananivas, Ashtaratha and Krishna Kshetra. Jagadeesha Goswami is appointed to coordinate the research work. This resolution was followed by Resolution No. 66 which read that the Deity worship research group and the full GBC body must approve the contents of the ISKCON Deity worship handbook before publication. So, in 1989, the GBC felt that Deity worship policies need to be set and for that they need the help of Shastra. A committee was made as per this decision, which in the following years, underwent some modifications to the constituent members of the committee. This committee did its research and submitted its report to the GBC. The GBC finally published the Deity worship manual in the year 1995 under the ISKCON GBC Press calling it the Pancharatra Pradipa. In this Deity worship manual, the procedure for Aarati is described as follows. In addition to the worship of Srila Prabhupada in his Guru Puja, one should also honour him when performing Aarati by presenting the Aarati items to Srila Prabhupada after presenting them to one's own spiritual master, then with the consciousness that you are offering it on behalf of your spiritual master and with the blessings of Srila Prabhupada and Lord Chaitanya, offer it with the full number of circles listed below to the main Deity. After offering the incense to the main Deity, offer it as Prasada to the Lord's associates in descending order and to the Guru Parampara Sr. to Jr. This may be done with seven or three circles for each personality depending on time allowance. Then distribute it with one or three circles to the assembled Vaishnavas as the Prasada of the Lord and his associates. So, as per the GBC of ISKCON Mumbai group, Aarati has to be offered in descending order. And how to offer the Aarati to the Deity? That is also described in the Pancharathra Pradipa, which says under the heading, how to offer each item as follows. Offer all the items, except the chamara and fan, by moving them in clockwise circles while ringing a bell with your left hand above waist level, fixing your attention on the Deities. Lamp: How to offer a lamp? That is described here. Lamp: Offer four circles to the lotus feet, two circles to the navel, and three circles to the Lord's face. Then offer seven circles to the Lord's whole body. Then the second one: Argya in a conch. Offer three circles to the Lord's head and seven circles to the whole body of the Lord. Then pour a small amount of the offered Argya into the Visarjaniya Patra, small throat pot, before proceeding to offer Argya to the next personality. Aarati Argya, plain or scented water. Then comes the cloth. Offer seven times around the Lord's body. Flowers: Offer seven times around the Lord's body. Chamara: Wave before the Lord a suitable number of times. Fan: Wave before the Lord a suitable number of times. So in 1995, the GBC approved the Manual for Deity Worship where when a devotee offers Aarati, he presents the Aarati to his Guru, then to Srila Prabhupad as a matter of honoring them and taking blessings from them. Then the arathi actually starts by offering it to Krishna first. 4, 2, 3, 7 formula for lamparathi, 3, 7 formula for water, etc. The key point is that the arathi offering begins with offering to Krishna on behalf of your spiritual master and then the prasadam is offered to Radharani, then to Mahaprabhu, then to Nithyananda Prabhu and then to Srila Prabhupada and then to your Guru.

This system was given a stamp of approval and finality by the GBC in the year 1995. Now, we must note that Srila Prabhupada had already established a systematic and elaborate system of Deity worship in ISKCON. Srila Prabhupada not only established the standards of Deity worship, Srila Prabhupada also ran it under his personal supervision in all the temples in ISKCON from 1967 till 1977. That is 10 straight years, if not longer. And this same system that Srila Prabhupada established continued for another 18 years or so till 1995 when the Pancharatrapadeepa came out. So, what was the system that Srila Prabhupada established for offering aarti to the deities? What was the original system? Was it the same as that instructed by the GBC in the Pancharatrapadeepa? Let us look at a few of Srila Prabhupada's directions in this regard. In a letter to Aniruddha dated 14th of November 1968, Srila Prabhupada instructed, aarti is performed at one and a half hour before sunrise to awaken the deities. Each offering is made by moving it in seven big circles, starting at the lotus feet of the Lord and going clockwise round. So, you see, no 4-2-3-7 formula. Straight seven circles. That's it. That means, the 4-2-3-7 aarti introduced by the GBC in the 90s is an outright deviation in deity worship. Are you stunned? Hold your breath because the worst is yet to come. Next comes the sequence of offering the aarti. In another letter to Giriraj, dated 28th of May 1972, Srila Prabhupada instructed, so far your question regarding deity worship during aarti, everything should be offered first to the Guru. So, Srila Prabhupada instructed to offer first to Guru, not to Krishna. And in his letter to Hemavathy dated 1st April 1970, Srila Prabhupada gave even greater clarity on the sequence or order of doing the aarti. Srila Prabhupada wrote, You have asked some questions. The order of worshipping is 1st spiritual master, 2. then Lord Chaitanya, then Radha Krishna, as in the mantras or Bendeyam prayer. So, here, very clearly, Srila Prabhupada gave an even greater clarity on the sequence and the position of doing the aarti. Very clearly, Srila Prabhupada said that we have to follow the sequence of Vandeyam prayers. And what is the sequence of Vandeyam prayers? First Guru, which is Srila Prabhupada, then Savadhootham or Sri Nithyananda Prabhu, then Lord Chaitanya, then Radha and then finally Krishna. It is the ascending order, not the descending order which the GBC has now implemented in ISKCON. Descending way is the procedure which was established by Srila Prabhupada for Deity worship in ISKCON from 1967 till 1977. And ISKCON continued with that system till in the late 80s or 90s, the GBC decided to change it entirely. Both the sequence of offering Aarati by completely reversing the order to begin the Aarati with Krishna, and also the number of times from just 7 straight times to 4, 2, 3, 7 etc. This is an outright outrageous deviation by the GBC of ISKCON Mumbai group. What audacity they must be having to change the Deity worship system. Is there no one in ISKCON to question such pernicious deviations by the GBC? Don't the GBC understand they are playing with something? Are they playing with something more dangerous than dynamite with the Deities? What is everyone doing in ISKCON? Are they all sleeping?

**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers

**Summary:** The speaker concludes by reiterating that the Rithvik system is not a reaction to guru fall downs, but rather the guru fall downs are a result of disobeying Srila Prabhupada's July 9th directive, emphasizing the directive as the sole authorization for Rithvik initiations.

For a detailed analysis of the May 28 meeting and the July 9 directive, please see the link below in the description. So, to conclude, from the history of ISKCON, we can see that the claim that the Rithvik system was a reaction to the guru fall downs and excesses of the zonal acharya system falls flat on its face. The Rithvik system has nothing to do with the guru fall downs. Whether gurus fell or not, irrespective of that, the Rithvik system is the only system authorized by Srila Prabhupada for carrying on initiations in ISKCON after his Thiro Bhava. Even if no gurus ever fell down in ISKCON, our stance will not change. In fact, rather than the Rithvik system coming up as a reaction to the guru fall downs or excesses of the zonal acharya system, the fact is the reverse. The guru fall downs and excesses of the zonal acharya system are a direct reaction of disobeying Srila Prabhupada's July 9 directive to conduct initiations in ISKCON via Rithviks on behalf of Srila Prabhupada. So, the claim that the Rithvik system of initiations is a reaction to guru fall downs is simply a desperate figment of imagination in order to discredit Srila Prabhupada's July 9 order, and it is nothing but a feeble attempt to give credence to the unauthorized guru system in ISKCON. In reality, the July 9 directive alone stands as the sole, unrivaled authorization of the system of Rithvik initiations in ISKCON. Hare Krishna!

#### Brahmana, spirit vs matter, detachment, duty, Dronacharya, Drishtadyumna
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/F6KbDAQAQrM?t=532
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Although the bodies are changing, I am still constant. That means I am different from all these bodies."
**Summary:** The speaker continues to explain the concept of a Brahmana and how Dronacharya, being a qualified Brahmana, understood his duty to impart knowledge to a qualified disciple like Drishtadyumna, despite knowing the consequences.

An intelligent person according to Krishna is able to discriminate that I was born as a small baby, I grew up into a young boy, then I become a young man and finally I will become old and I will die one day. So even within this lifetime, I have changed so many bodies. I had the body of a small baby, then that of a young boy or a girl, then that of a young man or a young girl. I may be a young person today. In the future I will become old. I may be a young person today. So within this lifetime, I am changing so many bodies. Although the bodies are changing, I am still constant. That means I am different from all these bodies. A person who is able to distinguish himself, differentiate himself from the material body which can undergo destruction and who understands by this logic that in this life if I can change so many bodies and continue to exist, that means at the time of death, the body which I currently have at that point of time will get destroyed. That means at the time of death, the body which I currently have at that point of time will get destroyed but I will continue to exist in some other body. A person who is able to understand this is called a brahmana. Now Dronacharya was a qualified brahmana. He very well knew that he was not the body. He was an atma. He was a spirit soul. Therefore when Drishtadyumna came in front of him with this kind of request, Dronacharya thought that what is my duty? My duty as a teacher is to teach the knowledge that I have. I have to teach the knowledge that I have to any qualified person who comes and seeks it of me. And this person Drishtadyumna is a qualified person. The knowledge which I will give to him, he will not misuse. He will not harm others with it. He will use it to protect the citizens. I can see that. And assessing that Drishtadyumna was a qualified disciple, Dronacharya accepted him under his tutelage. And he started teaching him the art of warfare along with the Pandavas and the Kauravas. He did not discriminate against him. This shows the great liberal mind of Dronacharya.

#### Dronacharya, Arjuna, Ashwathama, Drishtadyumna, liberal mind, merit, duty
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/F6KbDAQAQrM?t=664
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "Dronacharya went by merit and he went by what was the most appropriate thing, what duty called upon him to do."
**Summary:** The speaker highlights Dronacharya's liberal-mindedness by pointing out that he chose Arjuna as the greatest archer over his own son, Ashwathama, and that he taught Drishtadyumna, focusing on merit and duty rather than personal considerations.

In fact two things are very indicative of the liberal mindedness of Dronacharya. Although Dronacharya had a son Ashwathama, he chose to make Arjuna the greatest archer in the world. He taught Arjuna which he did not teach Ashwathama. Why? Because Dronacharya went by merit. He saw that Arjuna had a certain dedication and a certain talent which Ashwathama his own son did not possess. As a beautiful father he taught Ashwathama whatever he had to teach and he gave him a little more facility at certain times also. He was a little more lenient because after all he was his son. And nobody should criticize him saying that as a father he did not do anything for his son. Therefore he was a little more lenient with his son. But still when it came to certain very critical and advanced things Dronacharya gave that those kind of advanced knowledge to Arjuna which he did not give even to Ashwathama. This shows how Dronacharya was never partial. He went by merit and he went by what was the most appropriate thing, what duty called upon him to do. The second thing was the case of Drishtadyumna where Dronacharya considered that my duty is to teach Drishtadyumna. The result is I will get killed. Now I can refuse to teach him but still one day or the other this body has to get destroyed. I have to die one day or the other. One day or the other I have to leave this body and take on another body. So if I don't do my duty also I have to give up this body and if I do my duty also I have to give up this body. It is better that I do my duty and give up this body rather than to live with the ignominy that look at Dronacharya, he did not do his duty and to live with that ignominy is worse than death. It is better that I do my duty and lose my life in the process of doing my duty. And so saying Dronacharya very liberally he taught Drishtadyumna also. And during this time it so happened that having heard about the fame of Drishtadyumna, he came to Dronacharya and requested him to teach him the art of archery. But Dronacharya saw that Ekalavya would misuse the knowledge if it was given to him. And therefore Dronacharya refused to teach Ekalavya. This is generally a misunderstood phenomenon because people think that Dronacharya refused to teach Ekalavya. Ekalavya simply based on the caste in which he was born, which is not true. Because if Dronacharya had such considerations based on the body, he would never have taught Drishtadyumna, the art of warfare. Dronacharya was far far above all these things.

#### Dronacharya, Ekalavya, misuse of knowledge, duty, guru dakshina, compassion
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/F6KbDAQAQrM?t=1008
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "This assault rifle is not meant for shooting at dogs, it is meant for use in a circumstance where is there is danger to the life of the dog."
**Summary:** The speaker uses the analogy of an NSD commando misusing an assault rifle to explain Ekalavya's misuse of archery, emphasizing that Dronacharya took away Ekalavya's thumb to prevent further misuse of knowledge, not out of partiality or caste discrimination.

If the dog was disturbing you, all that you have to do was stick up a stone and throw it at it, no, you do not have to throw a stone at a dog. Even if you make a, even if you feign, as if you are going to throw a stone at the dog, the dog will quieten down or it will run away. This is natural. All of us would have experienced this at some time or the other. So similarly, when he, when Ekalavya came across a dog barking at him, all that he had to do was take a stone and throw at it. But what did he do? He decided to use that great art of archery against the dog. That poor dog became the object for Ekalavya to show off his art of archery which is not acceptable because the art of archery is a very very high level of knowledge to be utilized only for protection of people, not to harm people, whether any person, whether it is a human being or an animal. In Vedic times both human beings as well as animals were considered praja or the citizens of the country. Animals also had an equal right to be protected by the government unlike today's time. Today's time animals are sent to the slaughterhouses and all protection is given to the human beings. Vedic times was not like that. Even animals were protected by the government. Even animals were given the right of protection. So this Ekalavya did not display that sense of protecting subordinate people or junior people. A dog is a very subordinate animal. It was worthy of his protection but instead he was shooting arrows into his mouth. And he did not even consider now that all the arrows are stuck in the mouth of the dog, the poor dog how will it survive? What will it eat? So you can see from this Ekalavya was prone to misuse of the knowledge of warfare. And seeing this therefore Dronacharya did not want him to commit further crimes like this. And therefore Dronacharya told him okay you are considering me as a guru, you give me your thumb as guru Dakshina. And he took away his thumb so that the chances of his misusing the knowledge of archery would be reduced. Another thing Dronacharya could have easily done was to kill him. But Dronacharya was not so keen to kill somebody. He thought why I have to kill someone. Let me just take away his thumb. That is enough to prevent him from misusing the knowledge he has. And this was the reason for Dronacharya to do this.

#### Draupadi's disrobing, Yudhisthira's dilemma, Duty vs. Power
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/nFxsWxV9uTc?t=96
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "So does that not free the Pandavas from their binding to their words?"
**Summary:** The speaker discusses the events of Draupadi's attempted disrobing and questions why Yudhisthira and the Pandavas did not intervene, exploring the conflict between their duty as servants and their duty to protect their wife.

Hare Krishna and welcome to today's episode of the Mahabharata. In the last episode, we have seen that very painful incident of the game of dice, where Draupadi was attempted to be stripped naked by the Kauravas, headed by Karna, Duryodhana, Dushyasana, and others. And although Dushyasana tried his best to disrobe Draupadi, Draupadi surrendered herself completely to Lord Krishna, and Krishna in turn protected her modesty. And so, Dushyasana pulled and pulled at her Sari with great anticipation, but that anticipation turned to amazement when he saw an endless supply of her Sari covered cloth, and that amazement turned into frustration, that frustration became despair. Finally, he sat down fatigued, unable to disrobe Draupadi. Now, when the incidents had gone this far, Dhritarashtra had a change of heart. What did Dhritarashtra do? That is what we will be discussing today. Before we come to that, we need to understand a little bit about the whole egregious happenings in that game of dice. We all have understood how Yudhishtira was compelled to participate in the game of dice, not because he was inclined to it, but because it was the order of his superior, Dhritarashtra, whom he considered as good as his father. Now, although Yudhishtira knew that this was a trap laid out to hurt him and his brothers, Yudhishtira could not help it. He was looking towards Dhritarashtra's intervention to correct the injustice that was happening during the game of dice, but Dhritarashtra was silent all through. Now the question comes that when Draupadi was brought into that assembly and when her honor was being sullied by the Kauravas, why did Yudhishtira and the other Pandava brothers not act? Was it not their duty to protect the honour of their wife? Yes, it was their duty to the extent that their powers authorized them to protect her. We all have our limitations. Even though we may be wanting to protect our near and dear ones, there are some things which are beyond our power and we are unable to help them at times. This happens with all of us. Now in the case of the Pandavas, although physically they might have been capable of protecting her, morally they were bound by the word they had given to the Kauravas that they were now their servants. And as servants, it was their duty to do the bidding of their masters. So what use are such masters who do not protect the honour of their servants? So does that not free the Pandavas from their binding to their words?

#### Kshatriya Dharma, Duty of a King, Duryodhana's Adharma
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/nFxsWxV9uTc?t=322
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Now it was Duryodhana's duty as a king to protect the honor of the Pandavas, who are now also his citizens."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that the Pandavas, having lost their kingdom, were no longer obligated to protect others; instead, it became Duryodhana's duty as king to protect them, including Draupadi, and that Duryodhana failed in his dharma.

So does that not free the Pandavas from their binding to their words? The fact is, that the Pandavas having lost all their kingdom and having been stripped of their Kshatriya position, having become servants of Duryodhana, no more were they in a position to be able to provide protection to others. Protecting others, protecting the citizens is the duty of the Kshatriya. Kshata trayate yati kshatriya. The Kshatriya is the person who protects his citizens from any kind of danger. It is the Kshatriya king's responsibility to give protection to all his citizens. Now that the Pandavas were no longer kings, they were mere servants, they were mere ordinary citizens, under the rule of Duryodhana. Now it was Duryodhana's duty as a king to protect the honor of the Pandavas, who are now also his citizens. Now if Duryodhana is not following his duty, if he is deviating, if he is flagrantly flouting the codes of Dharma, according to which he has to protect the honor of his citizens and prevent any kind of danger, then he is a king. Any harm to them, whether physically or economically or in terms of their honor, if Duryodhana, the king himself is flouting these duties, then what can the citizen do? So the Pandavas, in fact it was the duty of Duryodhana to protect Draupadi. He was not keeping up his duty. It was the duty of Dhritarashtra to ensure that there was no injustice to the Pandavas and even he violated his duty. Now because Duryodhana and Dhritarashtra and Karna and Dushyasana, all these people they flouted their dharma, their duty does not mean that the Pandavas also should forget their duty. Actually this was the biggest difference between Yudhishthira and the other Pandava brothers and Duryodhana.

It did not matter to him that he was violating the codes of dharma. It did not matter to him that he was violating the rules of the Vedas. It did not matter to him that he was incurring grievous sin because of which he would have to suffer in the future. None of these things mattered to him. So Uddistira Maharaj, from the Pandava's consideration. They had been deprived of their authority to perform that function of protecting others the moment they were shown of their kingdom and they were converted into ordinary servants. We have examples of this in the Vedic history. Even though a person may be very well capable of defending himself, still in Vedic times the people would consider, is it my duty to defend myself or is it somebody else's duty. When Vishwamitra Muni was performing tapasya's and yajnas in the temple, he was not only in the forest, there was a demoness who was coming and creating trouble for him, not allowing him to carry out his spiritual duty. Vishwamitra Muni is such a powerful sage. Not only that, before Vishwamitra Muni became the sage, he had been a king, a very powerful valiant king. So, it is not that he was unaware of the techniques of combat, how to fight, where to fight, with an asura, with a demoness. It was not unknown to him. Not only that, as a sage, he had powerful mantras by the dint of his austerities with which he could have easily killed the demoness. But he did not do so. He considered, my duty as a sage, what is my duty? My duty is to engage in spiritual activities. Whose duty is it to ensure that my spiritual duty is fulfilled? That is his duty. His duties are carried on without any obstruction. It is the duty of the king. And therefore, Vishwamitra Muni went to Dasaratha Maharaj, who was ruling the kingdom at that time and he informed him, like this, there is this demoness who is creating trouble for me. So, you have to please solve my problem. And Dasaratha Maharaj immediately said, yes, I am ready. I will come myself. You are such a great sage. It is a shame that if I am not able to protect you, I will come myself. And then Vishwamitra Muni said, no, no, you don't have to come. This is not such a big thing. Then Dasaratha Maharaj asked him, then whom should I send? Vishwamitra Muni said, send your two young sons, Sri Ramachandra and Lakshmana with me, who were at that time just teenagers. Dasaratha Maharaj balked. He was daunted. Why? My sons? They are so tender. They are just teenagers. They cannot fight with Asuras. So, Vishwamitra Muni, please, you don't ask for them, I will come myself. Out of parental affection, Dasaratha Maharaj did not recognize the great valor and capability and strength, the unlimited strength of the Supreme Lord Ramachandra.

He was taken aback by Vishwamitra Muni's suggestion, but Vishwamitra Muni knows everything and he is aware that this is also an idea of Lord Ramachandra and so therefore, he insisted and took Lord Ramachandra with him and he taught Ramachandra all the art of warfare and then Lord Ramachandra used that art in defeating the demoness. So, you see how Vishwamitra Muni, although he knew the art of warfare, he did not engage in the war himself, the demons. He engaged the Kshatriyas, the king of that area, who was responsible, who was interested with that responsibility. This is because during those times, in the Vedic tradition and the Sanatana Dharma, the duties of different persons in the social functioning of the society was very well laid out. In today's world, unfortunately, that societal structure has completely collapsed of the Varnasthama Dharma. Now we do not have an understanding of what is duty at all. We think we mistake our vritti, our occupation to be Dharma, to be Karma, which is not correct. There is a big difference between vritti and Dharma. There is a big difference between occupation for one's livelihood and one's duty. We have duties towards all other rest of the society. We have duties towards our parents, we have duties towards our forefathers, we have duties towards the sages, who have given us transcendental knowledge, we have duties towards devatas, who are supplying us all kinds of natural facilities, such as sunlight and air and water etc. For our livelihood, we have duties towards all other domestic, even to domestic, animals like the cow and the dog etc which render us service. We have responsibilities, we have duties, we have obligations towards our other relatives, it may be my husband, it may be my wife, it may be my sister, my other relatives, my friends, whoever helps me in various activities, I have obligations towards all of them. There are duties prescribed in the Vedas for all this. So duty is completely different from occupation for one's livelihood. One may give up one occupation and take on another occupation, but one cannot give up one's duty. And as Lord Krishna himself says in the Bhagavad-Gita, one must not give up one's duty however imperfectly performed to take up the duty of some other person however perfectly they may be able to do it.

Shakuni informed Yudhisthira Maharaj and the rest of the assembly, whatever we played, we played and somehow we won, you lost, let us forget all those things. Now, it is a new game of dice and here the stakes are much higher. If Duryodhana and I lose in this game of dice, then we all Kauravas will leave our kingdom and we will live in the forest in exile for 12 years. And in the 13th year, we will live in some city or village or town, incognito, in disguise, such that nobody can recognize us. And if the 13th year we are able to pass successfully without your detecting us, where we are and who we are, then in the 14th year, you will return the kingdom to us. Suppose, in the 13th year of exile, you recognize us, you manage to find us out and you are able to spot us, you are able to see through our disguise and identify us, then we will go back to another 12 years of forest exile and one more year of incognito, living in incognito. And then Shakuni said, if we lose, this is the condition. And if you lose, the same conditions will be applicable to you. Look at Shakuni's cunning nature. He did not immediately say that, if you lose, these are the conditions. He said, if we lose, these are the conditions and if you lose, then same conditions will be applicable to you, making it appear very fair.

So the Srimad Bhagavatam says that this is the characteristic of the devotees of Krishna. The devotees, their thinking is, whenever they come across any difficulty in their life is, they think that this difficulty is coming into my life because of my past sinful activities. So, somebody may say, that okay, why don't the devotees go and pray to Krishna, please remove my difficulty? No, the devotees don't pray to Krishna to remove their difficulty. Why? Because the devotee thinks, that according to the sinful activities that I have done in my past, I should have got a mountain of miseries, but Krishna has reduced me to a small, mole hill and he has given. Look at Krishna's mercy. He has reduced my misery to such a small thing, that very easily I am able to tolerate it. So, a devotee never asks Krishna to remove his misery. A pure devotee always, whenever he comes across any difficulty in his life, in his heart he is not suffering any difficulty. He is only experiencing the bliss of Krishna's protection. See, this much distress has come in my life. If Krishna was not there in my life, I would have had to suffer much, much more, but Krishna has sent it as only a small, simple problem that very easily can be crossed over. This is how devotees are always wrapped in their love for Krishna. So also the Pandavas. Anyway that and all is separate. Now you get up and give way. So then the monkey said, see, it is very difficult for me to move. My tail is lying there. You, it is in one side. You remove my tail and then you walk across. So, then Bhima looked at him and he said, what monkey, you know, simply creating trouble for me. He wants me to pick up his tail and keep it aside. Okay, anyway, let me do it. He went and he used his left hand to pick up the tail of the monkey. Then Bhima is holding the monkey's tail and pulling. It is not moving. Bhima was little surprised. He thought very easily like, you know, monkey's tail, how difficult it is to move. So, then he thought very easily he will be able to move, but this is not moving. So, he was carrying his gada with him. He kept it aside and then he used his right hand also. With both hands, he started pulling. But this tail is not moving. So, Bhima realized, this is not some ordinary monkey and this is not some ordinary tail. So, he started putting his full effort because now, it was a matter. It was a matter of prestige for him. And he is using his full energy and power and he is perspiring, but this tail is not moving. Then Bhima stepped aside and he understood that this is not some ordinary monkey because Bhima's power is such that no ordinary person can face him and this ordinary monkey's tail is not able to lift. So, this is definitely some extraordinary being. So, Bhima stepped aside and then he apologized to the monkey. He said, it looks like you seem to be some celestial personality. You are not an ordinary monkey. I am sorry that I spoke to you in an insulting way. Please forgive me and please reveal yourself. Then this monkey looked at him and he said, you spoke about somebody called Hanuman, no? I am that Hanuman. Bhima was astonished. Oh, Hanumanji has come. He immediately offered his obeisances. So, then Bhima was very happy to meet Hanumanji because Hanumanji is also a great devotee of the Lord. Bhima is also a pure devotee of the Lord. So, then Bhima asked, requested Hanumanji to narrate the whole Ramayana to him. And so, Hanumanji very ecstatically, he described the whole Ramayana pastime of the Supreme Lord Ramachandra to Bhima. Then Hanumanji was carrying deities of Sita and Rama tied around his neck. So, he took those deities and he handed it over to Bhima and he gave it to him and he said, these are the deities of Lord Rama and Sita which were originally worshipped by Ikshwaku himself. And during Lord Ramachandra's personal presence, these deities were not being worshipped, but the Lord handed it over to one devotee in his kingdom who, because that devotee had taken a vow not to eat anything until he would have darshan of the Supreme Lord. This is the same devotee who had gotten the deities of Sita and Rama from Lord Ramachandra himself. And when that devotee, as long as he was alive, he was worshipping those deities of Rama and Sita. But when the time came for him to depart, to give up his body, at that time, he handed over these Sita and Rama deities to Hanumanji. And Hanumanji, from that time, was carrying it in a piece of cloth tied around his neck and every day, he would ecstatically worship them. And now, Hanumanji handed over the same deities to Bhima. So, Bhima received them with great respect and he took those deities. As long as Bhima was present on this earth, Bhima kept those deities very carefully and he would worship them every day. Of course, it is said that today, those deities were further, after the time of the Pandavas, were handed down further to their descendants and eventually, it reached the hands of Madhvacharya and he kept them in the Udupi temple. And it is said that even today, that Udupi temple, there are the deities of Sita and Rama, who are the same deities who were worshipped by Ikshwaku and then, handed over by Rama to his devotee, who handed it over to Hanumanji, who handed it over to Bhima and Bhima handed over to his descendants and finally, it is now in the temple of Udupi.

#### austerity, opulence, envy, contrast
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/aFCwu8RBOmw?t=93
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "In this way the Pandavas were going on accumulating pious credits. On the other hand Duryodhana was merely enjoying all the royal opulence and he was not engaged in conducting any fire sacrifice or yajnas."
**Summary:** The speaker contrasts the Pandavas' austere life in exile, focused on spiritual practices, with Duryodhana's opulent lifestyle and envy, setting the stage for Duryodhana's plan to show off his wealth.

Welcome to today's episode of the Mahabharata. In the last episode we have seen how the Pandavas, being in the forest exile, were engaged in executing various kinds of austerity. They were living in the forest, sometimes shuttling between Dwaitavana and Kamyakavana. They were living in simple thatched cottages with mud flooring. They were wearing dresses made out of tree bark. And they were constantly engaged in conducting yajna, sacrifices to please Lord Vishnu. And having obtained from the sun god, Suryadeva, a magical pot which could produce unlimited amount of food for feeding the guests. With that Draupadi would everyday cook and feed large number of saintly people who would come and attend the yajnas conducted by Yudhishthir Maharaj. In this way the Pandavas were going on accumulating pious credits. On the other hand Duryodhana was merely enjoying all the royal opulence and he was not engaged in conducting any fire sacrifice or yajnas. He was simply enjoying the power and opulence of the royal household and thus he was using up all his previous pious credits. Two contrasting things we were able to see. And when the Pandavas entered the twelfth year of their forest exile, Duryodhana based on the instigation by Karna decided to go to Dwaitavana to show off his opulence. How much wealth he had acquired and with all the women folk, with all the resources, with some small army with him. He wanted to go there and show off to the Pandavas because look out how I am enjoying life and how you people are suffering. During these twelve years, Duryodhana had spent time not only in increasing the strength of his army but also in striking of alliances with various friendly kings and he was like this building up his army power. So that he knew later when the Pandavas would come to seek their kingdom back, he could very easily rebuff.

**Summary:** The speaker narrates an incident in Dwaraka where Narada Muni witnesses Krishna's simultaneous presence in multiple palaces, highlighting Krishna's supreme nature.

We will begin today's episode with a small incident which happened in Dwaraka. Once Naradamuni, wishing to have darshan of Lord Krishna, because Naradamuni is a great devotee of Lord Krishna, he came to Dwaraka. Now when he came to Dwaraka, he saw that Dwaraka city was very opulent. And he found that there were 16,108 palaces, which Krishna had built for his queens, who also equally were equal in number to the palaces. Naradamuni thought, where will I find Krishna? So he randomly entered into one of the palaces. When he entered into the palace, Krishna was with one of his queens, playing with his children and Krishna very warmly welcomed Naradamuni, asked him about his well-being, etc. And then Naradamuni convinced Krishna to come to Dwaraka, to the palace and see what's happening there because Krishna is having 16,108. How is he managing all of them? We know how in this world today for one man is to manage one wife, he is, you know, his whole world will turn upside down. Now imagine not one, Krishna has sixteen thousand one hundred and eight wives to manage. So Narada Muni, being curious to know about this, he entered into another palace. There he saw Krishna was engaged in conducting some fire sacrifice, just like the yajnas are compulsory for every grahastha to be performed in the Vedic varnasama system. So because while walking, while drinking water, while breathing, while doing all these activities, we unknowingly commit sinful activities by stepping upon insects like ants, etc., and we cause deaths to them which actually accrue sinful reactions to us. Not only that, in the course of our earning our wealth, there will be some lies that we may have to speak, or they may be harmless lies, just like you go to a nearby kirana shop to buy your groceries and when you go there you ask him, ask the dhukandar, the owner of the shop, you ask him what is the cost of the dal. He will tell you the dal is 95 rupees per kg. You will say why it is so high. Then he will say no, for you at cost price I will give you 93 rupees. So you will also feel very happy, okay, two rupees discount and you will buy it. But you also know, shopkeeper also knows he cannot give it at cost price. If he starts selling his boots at cost price then he will heavily manage his family. So to just to give you a mental satisfaction he says for you I'm giving it at cost price. So this is a harmless life, but nevertheless it is still alive. Like this in earning our wealth we sometimes have to partake of sinful means to earn our livelihood. So in this many many ways we keep committing sins inadvertently although we may never intend to commit any sinful act. Therefore the Veda state every grahastha has to perform yajna to free himself of his of the sinful reactions which are accruing to him. Not only he has to do dana and he has to do tapasya, meaning he has to engage in fire sacrifice to please Lord Vishnu, he has to engage in activities of charity and he has to undertake some vrata, some austerities. These are compulsory for everyone. Charity was an obligation, it was not a choice. So Krishna, when Narada Muni came to this particular palace of Krishna, Krishna was engaged in doing some yajna. So then Narada Muni left that palace and entered another palace and there he saw Krishna was giving away cows in charity to some qualified brahmanas and he went to another palace. There he saw Krishna was engaged in advising his sons about the duality of this material nature and how we have to progress spiritually. Like this Narada Muni went from palace to palace. In every palace he saw Krishna was personally present and engaged in some activity or the other. So when Narada Muni saw this he was astounded. He was astounded because Krishna was personally present in each of those palaces individually. These were not illusory forms, they were Krishna himself.

Bhima killed a few other hundred soldiers. Arjuna also took care of a few hundred of them, Nakula also, Sahadeva also. And very quickly, in no time, Jaidratha saw that his whole army was completely vanquished. There was hardly anything left. And whatever little few people were surviving, they all ran away. And now Jaidratha is all alone. So Jaidratha realized, I had underestimated the strength of the Pandavas. So he thought, now, you know, Jaidratha, although he had on the spur of the moment, he had abducted Draupadi thinking that the Pandavas would be no match for him, at heart, actually, he was a very big coward. So when he saw that his whole army was finished, and he was all alone standing in front of these five Pandava brothers, he left Draupadi there, and he quickly took his chariot and started, you know, fleeing from the spot. So the Pandavas, now that they had dispersed the entire army, they quickly caught up with Draupadi. And the Pandavas inquired whether she was all right. And then Bhima and Arjuna told Yudhishthir Maharaj, that Maharaj, you please take Draupadi back safely to the hermitage. Nakula and Sahadeva will accompany you. We both will see to this Jaidratha. So Arjuna and Bhima continued in pursuit of Jaidratha. And Yudhishthira, Nakula, Sahadeva along with Draupadi, they returned to the hermitage. Now by the time the Pandavas had got back Draupadi, inquired about her welfare and sent her back along with Yudhishthira, Nakula and Sahadeva to the hermitage, by then, at great speed, Jaidratha had already crossed couple of miles beyond the Pandavas. So Jaidratha had got a head start. Now how to catch up with him? So Arjuna sent forth a few arrows in the direction where Jaidratha had gone. And those arrows quickly covered all the couple of miles which Jaidratha had already passed by and they went and killed Jaidratha's horses. So now Jaidratha was left without a chariot, so he started running away on foot. So when he was running on foot, Arjuna and Bhima on their chariots very quickly caught up with Jaidratha. And so they saw Jaidratha is running away. And behind him, Arjuna and Bhima are coming. And Bhima started calling out, Hey Jaidratha, where are you running? Stop! Wait! Stand there and fight with us! Jaidratha was in no mood to turn around. He simply kept running. Actually a Kshatriya is never supposed to run away from battle. And especially when he is challenged, he cannot turn away like that. Krishna says in the Bhagavad Gita, the character, real character of a real Kshatriya is Yuddhe Chaapalaayanam. In a battlefield, even if he is facing death, the Kshatriya, the true Kshatriya will never turn back. But Jaidratha was a Kshatriya in name only. He was actually a big coward. He was not qualified to be a Kshatriya. Kshatriya, the meaning of the word Kshatriya is one who protects his citizens from any kind of harm. He is called a Kshatriya. It was the duty of the Kshatriya to protect the citizens, bodily also and their honor also. A Kshatriya is always supposed to give special protection. Although generally the Kshatriya is supposed to give protection to the citizens, the Kshatriya has to give special protection to the children, to the women and to the elderly people and to the cows. These four were required to be given special protection by the Kshatriyas. Kshatriyas would sometimes abduct some girls with the intention of marrying them. But such girls would be unmarried girls and the intention in abducting them would be to marry them, not with any other evil intention. For a Kshatriya to set his eyes upon a married woman was a strict no-no. It was a forbidden thing. A Kshatriya could abduct an unmarried girl and marry her, but he could never set his eyes upon a woman he was already married. Draupadi was a well-married woman. She had children of her own. And Jayadratha was knowing this very well. And even though she expressed that she had no interest in Jayadratha, still Jayadratha abducted her. So this is completely against the codes of Kshatriya Dharma.

Now this Jayadratha, actually by trying to abduct the Pandavas wife, he had become an Atatain. In the Vedic terminology, there are kinds of Atatains or aggressors. A person who encroaches upon one's property, a person who administers poison, a person who abducts one's wife, a person who suddenly attacks one with deadly weapons without any prior notice. So all these kind of people are called Atatains or aggressors. And in the Vedas it is said that if somebody is an aggressor, is identified as an Atatain, then the person, the victim who is there, if he kills that Atatain, that aggressor, then there is no sin incurred in that. Even in the modern days we can say, we can see that the law will take a very lenient view if a man kills another man in self-defense. This is somewhat similar to that. But of course the Vedas were very specific and they had delineated the seven kinds of people in killing whom nobody could incur a sin and the king also could not punish such people. By abducting Draupadi, Jayadratha had become an Atatain, an aggressor. And according to the codes of Dharma, he was liable to be killed. So now Arjuna and Bhima, when they saw that Jayadratha is not turning around and he is not standing there for a battle, they pursued him and finally very quickly caught up with him. **Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5qdrfn8-qMY?t=1079
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "In other words, if we follow the path of Dharma in a gurusishya parampara which is stemming from one of these Mahajanas, then we will be able to understand what is the real goal of life."
**Summary:** The lecture emphasizes the importance of following a guru-shishya parampara (disciplic succession) stemming from one of the twelve Mahajanas to understand the real goal of life.

In other words, if we follow the path of Dharma in a gurusishya parampara which is stemming from one of these Mahajanas, then we will be able to understand what is the real goal of life. If we approach any gurusishya parampara which is not connected to one of these Mahajanas, then one cannot understand what is the real goal of life. For example, there are four sampradayas which are actually bona fide. One is stemming from Brahmaji himself which is called the Brahma sampradaya. And in this sampradaya comes Madhvacharya as well as Chaitanya Mahaprabhu and the Gaudiya Vaishnava sampradaya is also coming from the Brahma sampradaya. Then there is the sampradaya stemming from Lord Shiva which is called the Rudra sampradaya in which Vishnu Swami is the prominent Acharya. Then there is the Sri sampradaya stemming from Lakshmi Devi in which Ramanuja Acharya is the prominent Acharya. Ramanuja Acharya, Yamuna Acharya and many others in that sampradaya. The fourth one is the Kumara sampradaya stemming from the four Kumaras, the Sanath Kumaras who are the four sons of Brahmaji. They are the initiators of another sampradaya. And in this sampradaya, the prominent Acharya is Nimbarka Swami. If we want to understand the real conclusion of the Vedas, one has to be connected to one of these four sampradayas. Otherwise, it is not possible to understand the real conclusion of the Vedas.

**Summary:** The speaker explains that even though the scriptures are readily available, the true essence of Dharma remains hidden, and understanding requires connection to one of the four Vaishnava sampradayas.

Now why is it like this? This conclusion misses many people, all those people who are not connected to the sampradaya. There are more than 700 editions of the Bhagavad Gita in English alone in the market. But if you read them, you will never get this conclusion that Krishna is the Supreme Person and we are all His eternally, His part and parcel servants. Therefore, being pleased with you, I want to give you some boon. So please ask me whatever you would like to ask. And then Yamaraja replied to Yudhishthira Maharaj, My dear son, please know that the deer was not an ordinary deer, but it was I who took the form of a deer and took away the Arani sticks to lure you to this place so that I could test all of you. Therefore, I am immediately granting you the boon that you have requested for that the Brahmana's Arani wood, the wood for the fire sacrifice, I will return. And immediately he returned the firewood to Yudhishthira Maharaj. And after this, Yamaraja asked Yudhishthira Maharaj, My dear son, I am not satisfied with giving you this boon. **Summary:** The Pandavas return the firewood, spend the rainy season in the forest, and then decide to go to Viratanagara for their incognito exile.

Then taking the Brahmana's Arani firewood, the five Pandava brothers they returned and they handed over the firewood to the Brahmana and they continued to live in the forest for the next four months which were the rainy season. Generally in North India, the months starting from July up till about September, these four months are the rainy season. And during the rainy season, during those days, the practice was that people would not travel anywhere, they will stay wherever they are to avoid the troubles of walking through muddy patches of land and also the rainy season is the time when the forest become infested with snakes etc. It's not safe also to travel during the rainy season. So the Pandavas stayed in the Dwaitavana itself for the remainder of the rainy season and once the rainy season was over, the Pandavas started discussing amongst themselves that now the time has come that we have to live incognito. Now where do we go? After discussing various options, they decided that as per what Yamaaraj had blessed them with, they should go to the place known as Viratanagara. This Viratanagara was so called because it was being ruled over by King Virata and the kingdom was also known as the kingdom of Matsya. And this Matsya kingdom, some people say that it is in Rajasthan and Viratanagara is about 60 kilometers from Jaipur. Some other people say it is a place called Bhairhat in Bengal. Either way, it was quite a distance from wherever the Pandavas were there and they undertook a long journey by foot to cover the distance.

And being rebuffed like this, Urvasi being frustrated in her advances towards Arjuna, she cursed him that for one year he will have to become a eunuch. And the King Virata was also astonished. And he asked, who are you? Where have you come from? And why have you come to my court? Then this Brihannala, this eunuch introduced herself saying that my name is Brihannala. I am a eunuch and I have no parents. I know the art of singing and dance. So I am requesting you. Please appoint me to teach the art of dancing and singing to your daughter Uttara. The King Virata also looked at Brihannala and then he said that if you are truly a eunuch, I don't mind appointing you. And so he had a few maidservants from his palace inspect Brihannala. All of you are welcome to this next episode of the Mahabharata. Having now obtained the boon from Yamaraj, still the Pandavas felt it wise to disguise themselves and as advised by Yamaraj, they decided to go to the kingdom of Virata. And in the kingdom of Virata, the five Pandavas entered Virata separately. Yudhishthir Maharaj became Kanka, an advisor to the king. Bhima became Vallabha, a cook in the royal kitchens. Draupadi became Sairindri, a maid-servant who dresses the hairs for the queen of King Virata, Sudeshna. Arjuna became Brihannala, a eunuch, and he was appointed by King Virata to teach art of dance and music to his young daughter Uttara. In case they were in danger, because they were all entering separately and they were not in their disguise going to reveal that they were related to each other in any way, they would not be able to call out the names what they had assumed, nor could they call out their original names. So, in case of any danger and in case of need of any help, they decided on code names by which they would call each other. So, they gave themselves the names of Jayanta, Vijaya, Jaya, Jayat Sena, Jayat Bala. During these 10 months, the Pandavas were able to live peacefully. More or less, they were avoiding all attention. #### Arjuna's revelation, Duryodhana's plan
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/stjh4gHOQGk?t=150
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Now that the disguise of the Pandavas was discovered, Duryodhana became very happy."
**Summary:** Arjuna reveals himself as Brahmanala, leading to Duryodhana's elation due to the terms of the Game of Dice.

On the first day when the ally of Duryodhana attacked the kingdom of Virata, King Virata, accompanied by the four brothers, Yudhishthira, Bhima, Nakula, and Sahadeva, managed to defeat them. And when they were planning to return to the kingdom of Virata the next early morning, Duryodhana and his party attacked the kingdom of Virata. On the other end, in response to which, King Virata's son Bhuminjaya, along with Brahmanala, went to counter that attack. Now that this Brahmanala was Arjuna was unknown to anyone, but Brahmanala revealed to Bhuminjaya when he was completely taken aback by the force of the Kaurava army. Brahmanala revealed to him that he was Arjuna himself. And then Bhuminjaya agreed to become his charioteer. And thus, Brahmanala retrieved the weapons of the Pandavas, which were hidden in the semi-tree next to the crematorium. Now, having retrieved his Gandiva bow, Arjuna sat on the chariot and he blew his conch shell, the Devadatta. By the sound of the conch shell itself and looking at the Gandiva bow, the Kauravas understood that this was Arjuna.

Duryodhana came to Dwaraka and he informed the people there that he had come to meet Lord Krishna because he knew, although Ugrasena was the king of the Yadavas, still Krishna's word was always considered final in the Yadava assembly. So he thought it is wise to meet Krishna and if he seeks Krishna's support and Krishna agrees, then all the rest of the entire Yadava clan would definitely support him. So with this intention, Duryodhana had come to Dwaraka. In the meantime, what had happened is, before Duryodhana came to Dwaraka, Satyaki, one of the commander-in-chiefs of the Yadava army, he was a disciple of Arjuna. He had learnt the art of archery from Arjuna himself and he was always very much in favour of the Pandavas because of their righteousness. Satyaki, without waiting for an invitation from the Pandavas, took one Akshauhini, one division of army and went to Virata, the kingdom of Virata and he joined the Pandavas. Now the rest of the Yadava clan was still in Dwaraka by the time Duryodhana had reached Dwaraka and now when Duryodhana came and sought audience with Krishna, he was told that Krishna was taking rest within his chambers and so he was escorted, Duryodhana was escorted towards Krishna's chambers. Because Duryodhana, the entire Kaurava dynasty were closely related with the Yadava dynasty because Kunti Devi was from the Yadava dynasty and therefore she was the aunt of Lord Krishna and that way the relationship was quite thick between the Yadava household and the Kaurava household. So therefore, Duryodhana had access to Krishna's private chambers. When Duryodhana arrived, it so happened that Krishna was actually resting. He was sleeping in his inner chambers and because he was a close family member, he was escorted to Krishna's bedroom. As Duryodhana was entering Krishna's bedroom, he saw there was one more visitor who had arrived at the same time. It was none other than Arjuna. Arjuna had also come seeking the support of Krishna practically at the same time. Now Duryodhana and Arjuna saw each other, they greeted each other and Duryodhana entered first into Krishna's chamber because he had come first and also he was the elder one, Arjuna was younger. Giving due respect according to his age, Arjuna followed Duryodhana into the chamber.

Arjuna, he is a great devotee of Lord Krishna, and for him his heart is filled with love for Krishna. Yes, he understands the great position of Krishna as the Supreme Personality of Godhead. And then slowly Krishna raised himself up and he said, Oh Arjuna, you have come here. And then when Krishna got up and sat up on his bed, he saw Duryodhana is sitting next to him. And he said, Oh Duryodhana, you have also come. Then Krishna greeted both of them warmly and he asked them, Why have you both come at the same time together? At the same time to meet me? And since I have come here first, therefore I have the right to first ask your support. Lord Krishna replied to Duryodhana, My dear Duryodhana, I agree what you have said is right. You came here first. But when I opened my eyes, the first person I saw was Arjuna. Not only that, Arjuna is younger to you by age. And according to the Vedic scriptures, according to Dharma, the younger person is always given the first opportunity. And so therefore, I give Arjuna the opportunity to seek my support. But at the same time, what you have said is right, Duryodhana, that I am related equally to both of you. This is a family quarrel. And so, what I will do is, on one side, I present myself unarmed. I will not take up arms in the battle. I will not fight in the battle. But I will be there giving good advice and support. Moral support and advice will be there from my side. On the other hand, my entire Narayani Sena, the Yadavasanya will be available. So between the two of you, you can choose one of these two. And Arjuna, I give you the first opportunity.

He had thought that oh, Arjuna has got the first right, he will choose the Narayani Sena and I will be left with Krishna who is anyway not going to lift weapons. What is the point of having him then anyway on our side? Duryodhana was elated that Arjuna had made the foolish decision. And he thought, good, Arjuna has somehow, by some fluke, Arjuna has chosen wrongly. So Duryodhana, but externally, he was a greatly diplomatic person. He maintained a very calm exterior and neutral countenance he maintained. And he said, I think I don't have a choice now. Arjuna has already chosen, you have given him the first right. So I have to be satisfied with your Narayani Sena. Okay, all right. I'll be satisfied with that. Okay, thank you both of you. I'm leaving. And he said, he got up and he walked out. Now when Duryodhana walked out, Krishna looked at Arjuna and he said, Arjuna, I said, I will be, I will not take up arms. Then why did you choose me? You should have taken the army. The entire Yadava army was at your disposal. Arjuna immediately said, Oh Krishna, you are the supreme personality of Godhead. Wherever you are there, Lakshmi Devi is also there. That means all opulence is also there. All victory is also there. I am not bothered about winning or losing this battle. I want you. You are the person whom I want. You are the goal of my life. So I don't want anything else. Everything else is secondary. If you are there with me, for me, everything else is achieved.

And even if you give five villages, one for each of five brothers, we are ready to even accept that because we are Kshatriyas. Our duty is to rule. Krishna asked Arjuna, Arjuna, what is your response? And Arjuna responded, He said, Whatever my brother Yudhishthir Maharaj has said is fully right and I stand fully with him. If the Kauravas are ready to give back Indraprastha, we will maintain peace. Otherwise, my Gandiva will speak. We will not speak anymore. Then Krishna looked at Bhima and he said, Bhima, what do you have to say? Now what was Bhima's response?
