Now, how was Sanjaya received in the Kaurava palace? That is what we will see today. Before that, when the message was reaching all the kings all over the world about the impending battle between Pandavas and Kauravas, in the kingdom of Madhra, Madhra Desha, there was the king who was known as Shalya. He was the son of Somadatta and his brother was Burishtaba. His sister was Madhri, and Madhri, as we know, was married to Pandu. When the message of this impending fight between the Pandavas and Kauravas reached Madhra Desha, Shalya wanted to support the Pandavas naturally because they were his sister's sons, and so he took his army and set out to the kingdom of Virata. Now, when Shalya was taking his army and proceeding towards the kingdom of Virata, he found that all along the way there had been many nice encampments created for him and his soldiers to rest during the nights. They would travel during the day, and during the night they would set camp somewhere along the way, and wherever they were supposed to put camp, already tents were arranged, various arrangements were made for their food and for their secure resting during the night, and good drinking water was made available, clean water for their clothing, for their bathing, and for washing their clothes. All these arrangements were made. Shalya was very happy when he saw this. He was pleasantly surprised. So as they approached the kingdom of Virata, at every stage he found wonderful arrangements were made. Shalya was very happy. He was thinking that the Pandavas, knowing that I am coming to them for supporting them, have made such wonderful arrangements. Yudhishthira is really very grateful and kind. And when they were close to the kingdom of Virata, Shalya, being so happy with all the arrangements because it took him so many days to come from Madhurdesha till here, he could not contain himself, and he was saying, "Where is Yudhishthira? I really want to meet him. I cannot wait till I reach the kingdom of Virata to meet him. He has made such wonderful arrangements. I am really obliged to him." Please, he spoke to the servants who had been deployed there for taking care of the hospitality of King Shalya and all his retinue. He told them, "Please go and call Yudhishthira. I want to meet them." These servants started looking at each other and with a puzzled look they stepped out of the camp and they started talking to each other. "Shalya is talking of Yudhishthira, what is this? All these arrangements have been made by Duryodhana." So anyway, let us go and convey to Duryodhana. They went and conveyed like this to Duryodhana, "Like this, Shalya is really obliged, but he is thinking Yudhishthira has made all these arrangements and he wants to meet you to thank you and expresses indebtedness." Duryodhana smiled slyly. This was a cunning arrangement from him to make Shalya indebted so that he could seek his support. So in a cunning way, he wanted to divert Shalya to his camp, and now Duryodhana, now that he knew Shalya had taken all his hospitality and he was now indebted to him, Duryodhana came before him, and Shalya, when he saw Duryodhana, he was taken aback, and he said, "Duryodhana, what are you doing here?" Duryodhana said, "I am the one who have made all the arrangements for you and I have taken care of all your hospitality en route so that you don't have any difficulty in your travel." See how cunning Duryodhana is. Now Shalya felt trapped. To his nephews, but he landed up with Duryodhana, and he said, "Okay, Duryodhana, I have taken all your hospitality, so I am indebted to you. Now you please tell me whatever you want. I am ready to give. I cannot go back on my... this is my word of honor because it is... it is for a respectable man, if he has taken somebody's hospitality, he has to fulfill his obligation towards the host." Duryodhana then said, "I want you and your army to fight with me whenever we have to fight with the Pandavas." Now Shalya was in a fix. He said, "Duryodhana, what to do? I understand what you have done now, but now it's too late. I have also, without thinking, without asking, I enjoyed all the hospitality you have given me, so I'm obliged to... I'll keep my word of honor. I am a man of my word of honor, so I will, since you have asked me, I cannot refuse. I will fight on your side."

The spiritual world is called Vaikuntha, meaning it is Vigatakuntha, meaning it is the place where there is no misery at all. Hence, during the reign of Lord Ramachandra, the entire earth was ruled over by Lord Ramachandra. He was rid of all kinds of miseries; there were no natural calamities. The weather was always pleasant, with the summers and winters appearing like springtime without excessive heat or excessive cold. The earth always produced grains, fruits, and vegetables abundantly. No one ever went hungry. The pangs of old age and disease were unknown to the citizens. No son died in the presence of his father, meaning everyone lived long lives, and no one died young. In the beginning, you may not have the understanding that Krishna is Supreme Personality of Godhead, but anyway, I am told to chant Hare Krishna, I am chanting. Some mantra, we chant like that. But as we go on reading Prabhupada's books, we understand, oh yes, Krishna is Supreme Personality of Godhead. Krishna is not like other devatas. So divya jnana has started getting revealed within the heart. And also you understand, I am not the body, I am a spirit soul, I am Atma, I am not the Deha. Divya jnana is getting revealed within the heart. #### karma, sinful reactions, prarabdha, aprarabdha
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/EMAA-YunHpw?t=451
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Papa or the sinful reactions in our life are of two kinds: One is the propensity to perform sinful activities which comes because of our ignorance, and second, the way the sinful reactions manifest is in the form of suffering."
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the nature of sinful reactions, dividing them into the propensity to sin and the suffering they cause, further categorizing suffering into Prarabdha and Aprarabdha Karma.

So why? Because, Papa or the sinful reactions in our life are of two kinds. One is the propensity to perform sinful activities which comes by our, because of our ignorance. And because of our ignorance, that thinking that I am the body, I am not a spirit soul, we have committed so many sinful activities in our past life. So we get the propensity to perform sinful activities in our current life also, which is the result of sinful activities in our past lives. And second, the way the sinful reactions manifest is in the form of suffering. So there is suffering and when we speak of suffering on account of our accumulated sinful activities, reactions in our past lives, it again manifests in two types. One is Prarabdha Karma and another is Aprarabdha Karma. Prarabdha Karma means the results which are already manifested. This body which I have got is the result of my past activities. It is Prarabdha Karma. I have got a certain mind and intelligence that is the result of Prarabdha Karma. I might be suffering from some disease that is the result of my Prarabdha Karma. That means it is already manifest. I am already, I am already either enjoying or suffering the fruit of my past activity. The second type of sinful reaction is Aprarabdha Karma. Aprarabdha Karmam Kutam Bijam Falon Mukam. This Aprarabdha Karma is of three kinds. One is, it is in seed form. Another is sprouting. Another is the fruit which is not yet ripe. So the, when the sinful reactions in our life are accumulated like a mountain, they are all like the bija, like the seeds which you have accumulated within a jar of seeds. So when you keep the seeds in the jar, they will remain as it is.

Jnane Prayasam, Udapasi, Namantayeva, so, to surrender to Krishna, by rejecting Jnana Yoga, and, Sanmukharitam, Bhavadiyava Vartam, to constantly hear your glories, submitting his prayers to Lord Krishna. So, when Chaitanya Mahaprabhu heard this, Chaitanya Mahaprabhu said, Eho Yaha, now what you are saying makes sense. Why? Because, now there is some activity, spiritual activity. What is that? #### Satamprasangat, Kali Yuga, ISKCON, institutional place
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/eL2zRCTsgDM?t=1977
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "In Kali Yuga, the process of spiritual emancipation is, to glorify Krishna, in the association of other devotees."
**Summary:** The speaker emphasizes the importance of glorifying Krishna in the association of devotees (Satamprasangat) in Kali Yuga and explains why ISKCON and other institutions are necessary.

So, what happens is, this is a very powerful process, especially in Kali Yuga. What is that? That, we engage in glorifying Krishna, Satamprasangat, in association of other devotees. Satamprasangat means, in the association of pure devotees, and in a group, as a group, we engage in glorifying Krishna. So, this process, is very, very powerful. So, that is why, the Bhagavatam, actually if you see, the Bhagavatam, is, in many, many places, you will find, from the beginning till the end, the Bhagavatam is pushing this, principle, that is, is exposing this principle, is again and again, reiterating this principle, that, in Kali Yuga, the process, the process of spiritual emancipation is, to glorify Krishna, in the association of other devotees. In the earlier ages, we could perform spiritual activities, all alone. Bharat Maharaj, he gave up his whole kingdom, and he went to the forest, and practiced Bhakti, all alone. And he reached the stage of Bhavabhakti. And later on, of course, he again took the birth of Jadabharata, and continued. He did not join, and, you know, in a group, and became a Bhakta, and started getting trained, and all that. You know, he went to the forest, and he practiced. Dhruva Maharaj, at the age of 5 years, he went to the forest, all alone, and practiced. And within 6 months, he achieved perfection. And, we all in Kali Yuga, you know, we come and join, he is gone 24, 26 years old, and 20 years will pass, but still, we will, you know, we will be in, you know, we will never, you know, what he achieved. But then, Dhruva Maharaj did it all alone. He went to Dhrotila, in Vrindavan, and he practiced. In 6 months, he had Darshan of Vishnu. You take the case of Narada Muni, Narada Muni also, for a few months, during Chaturma, for 4 months, he served all the pure devotees. After that, he went to the forest, and practiced on his own, all alone. Whereas, in Kali Yuga, if you try to do that, all these great personalities, they went to the forest, executed Bhakti, and overcame Maya. If in Kali Yuga, we try to do, first of all, you will not find a forest. Even if you find a forest, you go there, he will not overcome Maya, Maya will overcome us. So, it is not possible in Kali Yuga, to practice Krishna Consciousness, all alone. So, in the olden ages, it used to be possible. That's why, in the olden age, there was no ISKCON, there was no organization. It's not that, Panacharya had to create an organization, and everybody would come and practice. This is a very novel thing, which is happening only in Kali Yuga, which was started by Shri Krishna. And this is not unique only to our Sampradaya, Gaudiya Vaishnava Sampradaya. Even Madhavacharya had an institution. Even Ramadhyacharya started an institution. Because, in Kali Yuga, you have to have an institutional place, where devotees can all come together, and jointly they can practice.

#### fearlessness, surrender, protection
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Mw4Wpx13HUw?t=0
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Taking shelter of the Supreme Lord brings actual fearlessness and therefore the demigods decided to take shelter of the Lord."
**Summary:** The speaker reads and explains a verse and purport from Srimad Bhagavatam about taking shelter of the Supreme Lord to overcome fear.

Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 6, Chapter 9, entitled, The Appearance of the Demon, Prithrasura. Text No. 21 śrī-devā-ūchuhu vāivambharāgnya-kṣitayastriloka brahmādayo ye vayam udvijantaḥ harāmayasmai balimantakosau vibheti asmādharanam tato naḥ translation and purport by His Divine Grace Śrīla Prabhupāda The demigods said the three worlds are created by the five elements namely ether, air, fire, water and earth, which are controlled by various demigods, beginning from Lord Brahmā. Being very much afraid that the time factor will end our existence, we offer presentations unto time by performing our work as time dictates. The time factor himself, however, is afraid of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Therefore, let us now worship that Supreme Lord who alone can give us full protection. Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda When one is afraid of being killed, one must take shelter of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. He is worshipped by all the demigods, beginning from Brahmā. Although they are in charge of the various elements of the material world. The words vibheti asmād indicate that all the demons, regardless of how great and powerful, fear the Supreme Personality of Godhead. The demigods, being afraid of death, took shelter of the Lord and offered Him these prayers. Although the time factor is fearful to everyone, fear personified is afraid of the Supreme Lord, who is therefore known as abhaya, fearless. Taking shelter of the Supreme Lord brings actual fearlessness and therefore the demigods decided to take shelter of the Lord.

#### Krishna's pastimes, motherly love, childhood behavior
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Mw4Wpx13HUw?t=150
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers, General public
**Key Quote:** "How Mother Yasoda can put me down when I am hungry and I am drinking her milk?"
**Summary:** The speaker narrates the Damodara Lila, focusing on Krishna's anger at Yasoda for leaving him to tend to the boiling milk and his subsequent mischievous act of breaking the curd pot.

When Kṛṣṇa had appeared 5000 years ago, He performed many wonderful pastimes, especially during His childhood. When Kṛṣṇa was about probably around one year old, once it so happened that Yasodamāyī was sitting in her house and she was churning the curd, nice freshly formed curd. She was churning to take out the butter, so that she could feed Kṛṣṇa with it. And Kṛṣṇa at that time, He was feeling hungry. He walked up to His mother and started pulling her, pestering her, that I am hungry, I want milk. Yasodamāyī stopped her churning, took Kṛṣṇa on her lap and started feeding Him her breast milk. And while Kṛṣṇa was drinking His mother's milk, suddenly Yasodamāyī noticed on the fireplace, she had placed one pot of milk to boil. And this milk was a special milk which was meant for feeding Kṛṣṇa. And that milk started boiling and overflowing. Yasodamāyī immediately, she thought, oh, if this milk boils over and it gets burnt, then what will my Kṛṣṇa drink? So she immediately removed Kṛṣṇa from her lap, set Him down and ran to the kitchen. To remove the milk from the fireplace. And it would have taken some time, she had to remove the milk and then put off the fire and if some milk had been spilt over, clean up and all those kind of things. Some time it took and she came back. Now in the meantime, our Kṛṣṇa is not someone who is going to wait for anyone. He got very angry. How Mother Yasoda can put me down when I am hungry and I am drinking her milk? How she can put me down and go away? So Kṛṣṇa became very angry. I will show her what I am. So He looked around and what to do? He looked at the pot of curd that Mother Yasoda had been churning. He took a stone and broke that pot. And even, you know, all small children also when they get angry, they will do something naughty like that. And after they do it, then they will start thinking, now what is going to be the consequence? You know, when we grow up, we first think of the consequence and then we act. Children are not like that. They first act and then think of the consequence. So Kṛṣṇa also broke the pot. After breaking the pot, He started thinking, okay, my anger, Bhadas nikal diya. I, you know, I showed my anger, broke the pot. Now Mother Yasoda will come. What is going to happen? So better I scoot from here. Better I don't stay here. So silently, He slipped away from there. So Yasoda Mai, after cleaning up the kitchen or whatever, she came back and she saw, Krishna is not there. Okay, Krishna must have gone. He must have gone to play or something. But then she saw that the pot of curd has been broken and the curd is all spilled over. So she thought, who can do this? Nobody can come into the house and do all this. Krishna only must have done this. She deduced. After all, she is a mother. She knows her son. Who can know her son better than her? So she thought, Oh, Krishna, you are doing like this. I will teach you a lesson today. She started searching. Where is Krishna? Where is Krishna? Where is Krishna? And searching, searching, she came to the storehouse where Krishna was sitting and he was taking out the butter and he was feeding all the monkeys. So silently, Yasoda Mai walked up behind him, wanting to catch him. But suddenly, Krishna turned and saw, Oh, Yasoda Mai is coming. He left everything and started running. Yasoda Mai also started. She was also not going to give up. Today I have to teach him one lesson. Determined. And she ran after him and Krishna is also running. Yasoda Mai is running. And you know how difficult it is to catch children. Although they are so small, if they start running, so difficult it is. Like some of our temples, we will be doing ICVK. Right? In the, for small children, even in Chennai also, we have started ICVK. Some, some small kids, in that three to five year age guru, they will not sit quietly. They will keep running around and, and the teacher, to control the child, it is very difficult. So, she ran after him and Krishna is also running. Yasoda Mai is running. And you know how difficult it is to catch children. To control the child, it will, you know, she will be totally fed up. She will not be able to do it. So, children are like that. So, Krishna is running. Yasoda Mai is trying to catch, but she is not able to capture him. And, the laborious, you know, running, running, running. She was panting and she was perspiring. But she was also not giving up. Somehow, I am going to catch Krishna today. I am not going to give up. So, Krishna also saw that his mother has become tired. She is perspiring. And, she is, you know, breathing heavily. So, Krishna allowed himself to be captured by Yasoda Mai. Yasoda Mai caught him. And then, when she caught him, she saw Krishna was crying out of fear. What is mother is going to do now? I broke the pot. So, already in fear of the punishment, he had started crying.

Sometimes, it happens, no? We all, as children, if you remember, when we were in classroom, something we did, show your hand and took the scale. Before the teacher lifts this one itself, we will start crying. And, teacher will say, hey, what did I do? First, you show your hand. Don't cry. So, children are like that. So, Krishna also, Yasoda Mai is going to punish me today. He started crying. And, Yasoda Mai had applied nice mascara to Krishna's eyes. All that mascara is flowing down Krishna's cheeks. And, Krishna is in great fear. And, Yasoda Mai saw that Krishna is crying so badly. It's not good that he feels so afraid. My child should not be so much afraid of me. So, she saw in her hand, there was a stick. And, seeing the stick, she saw Krishna is becoming so afraid. So, she thought, okay, let me not beat him with this stick. She threw away the stick. But then, still punishment has to be there. Otherwise, Krishna will every time do something, even bigger. So, she saw there was a wooden mortar there. And, she took some rope and tied Krishna to it. So, you are being so naughty. So, I am punishing you. So, for some time, you remain there. Let us see what you do. So, she tied him to the wooden mortar. And, Krishna was hardly about a year old. So, Yasoda Mai then tied him and then went off. And then, Krishna thought, oh, Yasoda Mai has tied me. She tied me for breaking that pot of curd. Now, I will do something even bigger. Let us see what she will do. So, he thought what to do. And, he saw in the courtyard of Nanda Maharaj, there were two tall Arjuna trees, Yamala Arjuna trees. So, Krishna started crawling. Because, you know, one year old children, they will sometimes crawl. They will sometimes walk also. It is like that. So, Krishna started crawling. And, crawling, crawling, pulling the wooden mortar which got stuck between the two trees. And, what happened? The two trees fell down. And, out of that, two dazzling, effulgent personalities came out. They were, you all know who they are, right? Who are they? Nalakuvara and Manigreeva, the sons of Kubera. So, they came out and they offered their obeisances to Krishna. They offered their prayers and they got liberated. In the meantime, the Gopas Yashoda Mai, they all came running because two huge trees falling. They made a thundering sound. So, everybody came running out. What happened? What happened? And, they saw two trees have fallen down and Krishna is between them. So, they all thought, Oh, great fortune. Narayana has protected him. Otherwise, the trees could have fallen on Krishna. What would have been his state? He would have been crushed. So, Yashoda Mai also took Krishna and then she did not she did not chastise him or anything thinking, you know, like this. Several decades later, Krishna grew up. He got married to 16,000 princesses. He had sons, grandsons, great-grandsons. He had built Dwaraka, ruling over Dwaraka with all the Yadavas. And then, the Pandavas had also grown up. They were Krishna's cousin-brothers and they had they had become very close associates of Krishna. And the Pandavas went through many tribulations and finally, the battlefield, the battle of Kurukshetra was fought and the Pandavas got back the kingdom. By this time, Krishna had already crossed the 90 years. He was more than 90 years old. So you can see, he had, he had, you know, more than nine decades had passed. And after Yudhishthira Maharaj was enthroned as the emperor, Krishna stayed for a few months in Hastinapura to please Yudhishthira and then after a few months, then Krishna said, all the residents of Dwaraka will be waiting for me, so I have to go now. So the Pandavas assembled and Satyavati also came, although she was very old, she was also there, Shantanu's wife and the, you know, Draupadi came, Kunti Maharani came, all the Pandavas, they all came, Uttara also came, they started offering their prayers to Krishna. **Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/m-JB2-c4bFo?t=0

**Summary:** This segment establishes Lord Ramachandra's enduring glory and asserts his divine status based on Vedic declarations, specifically referencing the Srimad Bhagavatam.

Although Lord Ramachandra appeared such a long, long time ago, still his glories are spread everywhere. The activities of the greatest of the human beings, be they emperors or world conquerors or big, big philosophers, are forgotten after a few hundred years. During his time, Alexander must have been world famous, but today we know very little of him. In a few more decades, he may even be forgotten from the minds of the people. However, Lord Ramachandra continues to rule the hearts of people even after millions of years. Why? Because he is not an ordinary man. He is God. How do we claim that Lord Ramachandra is God and not an ordinary man? We do not claim that Lord Ramachandra is God and not an ordinary person? The basis for determining who is God or who is an incarnation of God and who is not, is not just on the basis of popularity. The basis are the Vedas. The Vedas must declare that this person is Bhagavan or God. In the first canto of the Srimad Bhagavatam, there is a description of the different incarnations or avatara of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. One of them is mentioned as below: Naradevatvam Aapan Naha Surakarya Chikirsaya Samudra Nigraha Dini Chakrae Veeryaaniyata Param. In the 18th incarnation, this is what this verse of the Bhagavatam is saying. In the 18th incarnation, the Supreme Lord appeared as King Rama. In order to perform some pleasing work for the demigods, for the devatas, he exhibited superhuman powers by controlling the Indian Ocean and then killing the Atheist King Ravana who was on the other side of the sea. This is what the Srimad Bhagavatam says. So,

#### Vedic Time Scale, Samvatsaras, Vedic Astrology
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/vpe776XCgDc?t=101

What this mantra essentially does is to locate the space and time of the event. When we say Jambudvipa, Bharatavarsha, Bharatakhanda, Merohodakshinaparshva, what is happening? It is locating our current position within the universe. And as far as time is concerned, this is how we are located. We are right now in the Shubhakrit Samvatsara. What does this mean? In Vedic astrology, the Samvatsaras are years which are calculated in terms of the time Brihaspati or Jupiter takes to traverse the 12 Rasis. This comes to about 360 days to traverse one Rasi. One cycle of Brihaspati to cover all the 12 Rasis comes to 12 Samvatsaras. One Chakra or cycle of Samvatsaras is 5 cycles or 60 Samvatsaras. Each of these 60 Samvatsaras is given a particular name. And the first Samvatsara is called Prabhava. We are currently in the 36th Samvatsara by the name Shubhakrit. Hence, in the Sankalpa Mantra, we say Prabhavadi Shashti Samvatsarana Madhe Shubhakrit Nama Samvatsare. Shashti means 60. Samvatsarana Madhe means in the middle of the 60 Samvatsaras. Prabhavadi means beginning with the Samvatsara named Prabhava. Shubhakrit Nama Samvatsare means in the Samvatsara by the name Shubhakrit. The 36th Samvatsara in the middle of the 60 Samvatsara cycle is called Shubhakrit.

Simultaneously, Srila Prabhupada stitched together the disparate but sincere attempts of his disciples into a coherent force resoundingly heard across countries. The world sat up and took notice, not because of the genius marketing strategies, masterminded by some devotee, but by the transcendental vision and potency of the pure devotee, Srila Prabhupada.

#### Diksha, initiation, transcendental knowledge
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/yMdIaIRgz-g?t=533
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "Diksha is the process by which one can awaken his transcendental knowledge and vanquish all reactions caused by sinful activity."
**Summary:** The speaker defines Diksha (initiation) according to Srila Jeeva Goswami, emphasizing the awakening of transcendental knowledge and the vanquishing of sinful reactions as its core essence.

how does Srila Prabhupada define Diksha or initiation? Srila Prabhupada, in his purport to verse number 331 of chapter 24 of the Madhya Leela of the Chaitanya Charitamrita, mentions, "As far as Diksha is concerned, one should consult Madhya Leela, chapter 15, verse 108." And if we go to Chaitanya Charitamrita, Madhya Leela, chapter 15, verse 108 purport, there Srila Prabhupada says, "Srila Jeeva Goswami explains Diksha in his Bhakti Sandarbha, verse 283: divyam jnanam yato dadyat kuryat papasya sankshayam tasma dikshe tisa prokta desikais tattva kovidaihi. Diksha is the process by which one can awaken his transcendental knowledge and vanquish all reactions caused by sinful activity. A person expert in the study of the revealed scriptures knows this process as Diksha." So, essentially, as per the definition given by Srila Jeeva Goswami, Diksha or initiation constitutes two fundamental things: One is awakening transcendental knowledge and the second is vanquishing all sinful reactions. This is the real essence of Diksha or initiation.

#### Diksha, initiation, components
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/yMdIaIRgz-g?t=634

Now, let us list down some of the commonly understood components of initiation or Diksha. Some of them are like this: 1. The spiritual master gives instructions to the disciple about his service. 2. The disciple inquires about his spiritual doubts from the spiritual master, from the Diksha Guru. 3. The disciple serves the spiritual master by carrying out his instructions. 4. The disciple surrenders to the Diksha Guru. 5. A fire yajna is conducted to formalize the acceptance of the spiritual master by the disciple. 6. After the yajna, a new spiritual name is given to the disciple. 7. Sanctified beads are handed over to the disciple who vows to chant the prescribed number of rounds of Hare Krishna Maha Mantra on those beads. All previous karmic reactions of the disciple are destroyed. This is point number 8. And point number 9: Transcendental knowledge is revealed in the heart of the disciple by the Diksha Guru. Number 10: The Diksha Guru takes responsibility to take the disciple back to Godhead. So, these are some of the commonly understood components of initiation or Diksha.

#### Diksha, initiation, aspects

All these components of Diksha or initiation may be summarized in a table as you can see on the screen now. Under the first column of physical or personal aspects are listed the activities of Guru instructs on service of the disciple. Disciple carries out the instructions of the Diksha Guru. Diksha Guru clears the spiritual doubts and corrects the disciple's mistakes. These activities require a physically present person to instruct, to correct, to clear specific doubts, etc. Hence, we have included them under the physical or personal aspect. Now, under the second column of ceremonial aspects are listed the activities of formal surrender by the disciple to the Diksha Guru, formal acceptance by the Diksha Guru of the disciple, initiation yajna, Diksha yajna, initiation sacrifice, sanctified beads being handed over to the disciple, and new spiritual name being selected for the disciple. These are generally related to the initiation ceremony or the Diksha ceremony. Therefore, we have called this the ceremonial aspects of Diksha. Under the third column of transcendental aspects are listed the activities of disciple accepting the Diksha Guru in his heart and vice versa, the Guru accepting the disciple. Then the Guru reveals transcendental knowledge in the heart of the disciple. Then the Diksha Guru destroys previous karma of the disciple and the Diksha Guru takes the disciple back to Godhead.

#### Deity worship, initiation, material conditioning
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/yMdIaIRgz-g?t=1830
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Deeksha is the process by which one can awaken his transcendental knowledge and vanquish all reactions caused by sinful activity."
**Summary:** The speaker quotes Srila Prabhupada on the importance of Deity worship as a means to rectify material conditioning and establish a personal relationship with the Lord through initiation.

Further, in the same purport, Srila Prabhupada says, "It is Srimad Bhagavatam's opinion that the process of Deity worship is not actually necessary. Just as the specific prescriptions of the Pancharatra and other scriptures do not have to be followed, the Bhagavatam enjoins that even without practising Deity worship, one can achieve the complete success of human life by any of the other devotional processes, such as simply offering oneself at the Lord's feet for His protection. Nonetheless, Vaishnavas following the path of Sri Narada and his successors endeavour to establish a personal relationship with the Lord by receiving the grace of a bona fide spiritual master through initiation, and in this tradition, the devotees are obliged at the time of initiation to begin engaging in Deity worship. Although Deity worship is not essential, the material conditioning of most candidates for devotional service requires that they engage in this activity. When we consider their bodily and mental conditions, we find that the character of such candidates is impure and their minds are agitated. Therefore, to rectify this material conditioning, the great sage Narada and others have at different times recommended various kinds of regulations for Deity worship." As we can see, the transcendental aspect of initiation consists of destroying the sins of the disciple, awakening the transcendental knowledge in the heart, and taking the disciple back to Godhead, which are actually the crux or the heart or the essence of initiation or Diksha.

The very fact that Srila Prabhupada built up this system of initiations over several years between 1970 and 1977 just like he did with all other aspects of the transcendental organization of ISKCON speaks volumes about the efficacy and authenticity of the Rithvik system. This Rithvik system of initiations was given to us by a fully enlightened personality with transcendental vision. Any other system developed by persons who are not similarly enlightened is fraught with dangers and pitfalls. Like Srila Prabhupada often quoted Prahlada Maharaj who said that blind people following blind leaders are bound to end up in a ditch. #### Diksha Guru, Holy Name, Deliverance, Responsibility, GBC Resolution Critique
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/73UzAo_MtgY?t=429
**Verse References:** CC Madhya 9.61
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees
**Key Quote:** "On the other hand, the responsibility of delivering the disciple is taken by the Diksha Guru, solely by the Diksha Guru."
**Summary:** The speaker addresses the role of the Holy Name and other devotional practices, stating that the Diksha Guru is the primary deliverer, empowered to engage the disciple in these practices, and criticizes the GBC's resolution for diluting this responsibility.

So, then the question may arise, what is the role of the holy name and all the other items mentioned as the combined deliverers in the GBC resolution like the holy name, the Siksha Gurus, etc. Well, Shaila Prabhupada says this in the purport to the 61st verse of chapter 9 of Madhya Leela in the Chaitanya Charita Amrita. "It is the spiritual master who delivers the disciple from the clutches of Maya by initiating him into the chanting of the Hare Krishna Maha Mantra." So, we can understand that the deliverer is one. And who is that? The Diksha Guru. To deliver the disciple, the Diksha Guru initiates him into chanting the holy name, performing Navaveda Bhakti, worshipping the Deity, etc. Yes, all these are essential in the deliverance of a conditioned soul. But if we ask, who delivers the devotee? The answer is not that it is Krishna through a combination of Diksha Guru, Siksha Guru, holy name, Navaveda Bhakti, etc. as erroneously resolved by the GBC of ISKCON Mumbai group. On the other hand, the responsibility of delivering the disciple is taken by the Diksha Guru, solely by the Diksha Guru. We have to understand that everyone's responsibility is nobody's responsibility. The holy name may be there. Krishna may be there. Siksha Gurus may be there. Navaveda Bhakti may be there. Deities may be there. But one person has to take the responsibility of delivering the disciple. It cannot be left to some vague combination of everyone together delivering the devotee. That one person who takes the entire responsibility of delivering the disciple is the Diksha Guru. For delivering the disciple, the Diksha Guru is empowered by Krishna to engage the disciple in worshipping the holy name by chanting a prescribed number of rounds, in worshipping the deity, in executing Navaveda Bhakti, etc. In other words, if one chants the holy name, executes Navaveda Bhakti, hears many Siksha Gurus, but doesn't have a Diksha Guru, then none of them will take responsibility to deliver the devotee. Only when the devotee surrenders unto a bona fide Diksha Guru, will the Diksha Guru take responsibility to deliver the disciple.

So, it is clear that the holy name, Navaveda Bhakti, Shastra, the Guru Parampara, etc. are all acting to deliver the devotee. But, without the grace of a bona fide Diksha Guru, it is impossible to be delivered. Eventually, as Srila Prabhupada said, if a devotee doesn't have a bona fide Diksha Guru, but is chanting the holy name, executing Navaveda Bhakti, etc., then, the Paramatma will guide the devotee to a bona fide Diksha Guru, and then, that bona fide Diksha Guru will take the disciple back to Krishna, back to Godhead, delivering him from the material entanglement. Srila Prabhupada says, in his purport to the verses 8 through 12 of the 13th chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, "Because a bona fide spiritual master is a representative of Krishna, if he bestows any blessings upon his disciple, that will make the disciple immediately advanced without the disciples following the regulated principles. If the Diksha Guru bestows his blessings upon his disciple, then, the disciple becomes immediately advanced without following any of the regulated principles like Navaveda Bhakti, chanting prescribed number of rounds, etc. That is the power of the bona fide Diksha Guru. And where does the Diksha Guru get such power? From Krishna Himself. Because it is Krishna who has directly empowered the Diksha Guru like that. But, the GBC of ISKCON Mumbai group has diluted the power of the Diksha Guru by saying that it is not the Diksha Guru who delivers the disciple. Rather, it is Krishna through many many manifestations of His mercy.

Another point is that disciplic succession does not mean one has to be directly a disciple of a particular person. Arjuna accepted Krishna as the Supreme Personality of Godhead and we also accept the same truth under the disciplic succession of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. Things equal to the same thing are equal to one another. This is an axiomatic truth. So, there is no difference of opinion of understanding Krishna between ourselves and Arjuna. Another example is that a tree has many branches and you will find one leaf here and another leaf there. The predecessor Guru might order this devotee who is initiated from a different branch to become the next Guru in his line. So, both are initiated by pure devotees. Both are pure devotees themselves. The Rithvik process is independent of whether the Guru Parampara is Siksha or Diksha Parampara. Whether the Guru Parampara is Siksha or Diksha Parampara, has no relevance to the process of taking Diksha from Srila Prabhupada via the Rithvik system personally instituted in ISKCON by Srila Prabhupada. Thus, the Rithvik system does not violate any principle, even if our Guru Parampara is considered to be based on Siksha and not Diksha. All devotees are requested to reject the self-appointed no objection Guru system promoted by the GBC of ISKCON Mumbai. Instead, please take shelter of the Rithvik system ordered by Srila Prabhupada on July 9, 1977 and followed by the GBC of ISKCON Bangalore.

#### purport, creation, prakriti, purusha, supreme cause
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/pd1f-WBVQec?t=167
**Verse References:** BG 9.4, BG 7.5, BG 7.4, BG 10.8
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Therefore, the Supreme Lord is the cause of Prakriti and Purusha. He is the original cause, Sarvakarana Karanam."
**Summary:** The speaker reads and explains the purport, emphasizing Vishnu as the original cause of creation, Prakriti, and Purusha, referencing Sridhar Swami's commentary and various scriptures.

Purport. In this verse, the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Vishnu, is ascertained to be the original cause of creation. Sridhar Swami, in his commentary, Bhavarth Deepika, replies to the idea that Prakriti and Purusha are the causes of the cosmic manifestation. As stated here in Param Pradhanam Purusham Vishvamanyam, he is the Supreme. He is the supreme cause, represented as the male and female creative energies. All the different from this universe, he exists in his universal form, Virata Rupa. The word Prakriti, which is used to indicate the source of generation, refers to the material energy of the Supreme Lord, and the word Purusha refers to the living entities, who are the superior energy of the Lord. Both the Prakriti and Purusha ultimately enter the Supreme Lord, as stated in the Bhagavad Gita, Prakritim Yanti Maam Ikam. Although Prakriti and Purusha superficially appear to be the causes of the material creation, both are emanations of different energies of the Supreme Lord. Therefore, the Supreme Lord is the cause of Prakriti and Purusha. He is the original cause, Sarvakarana Karanam. The Naradya Purana, Avikaropi Paramah Prakritistu Vikarini Anupravisya Govindah Prakritishchabhidhiyate Both the Prakriti and Purusha, which are inferior and superior energies, are emanations from the Supreme Personality of Godhead. As explained in the Bhagavad Gita, Gama Vishya The Lord enters the Prakriti and then the Prakriti, and creates different manifestations. The Prakriti is not independent or beyond his energies. Vasudeva, Lord Shri Krishna, is the original cause of everything. Therefore, the Lord says in the Bhagavad Gita, Aham Sarvasya Prabhavo Matta Sarvam Pravartate Iti Matva Bhajante Maam Buddha Bhava Saman Vitaha I am the source of all spiritual and material worlds. Everything emanates from me. The wise, who perfectly know this, engage in my devotional service and worship me with all their hearts. In Srimad Bhagavatam, the Lord also says, Aham Evasam Evagre Only I existed before the creation. This is confirmed in the Brahmanda Purana as follows: Smritir Avya Vadhanena Prakrititvam Iti Sthithi Ubhayatmaka Suthitvadha Vasudeva Parah Puman Prakriti Purushad Cheti Shabder Ekobhidhiyate To generate the universe, the Lord acts indirectly as the Purusha and directly as the Prakriti. The energies emanate from Lord Vasudeva, the all-pervasive, supreme personality of Godhead. He is known as both Prakriti and Purusha. Therefore, Vasudeva is the cause of everything. Sarvakarana Karanam

#### Vritrasura, Indra, yagna, mantra, fear, shelter
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/pd1f-WBVQec?t=391
**Verse References:** —

**Key Quote:** "So now Indra and all the devatas are seeing this personality and they have no clue from where he has appeared and how he has appeared and they all become very very afraid and now they have taken shelter of the Supreme Personality of Godhead for protection"
**Summary:** The speaker narrates the story of Vritrasura's appearance and Indra's fear, explaining how a mistake in chanting a mantra led to an unintended outcome, and how the demigods sought protection from the Supreme Lord.

So in this chapter, chapter 9 of 6th canto, the appearance of demon Vritrasura. So we know the story how the demon appeared. Indra, he killed his priest because he was chanting the mantras favoring the demons. So Indra becomes very afraid and kills him. And then his father becomes upset because his son is killed. So his father, Tvashta, is performing a sacrifice by which a personality will be born who will kill Indra, because Indra killed his son, that is Visvarupa. So Visvarupa was the priest that Indra had engaged and he killed his own priest because he was favoring the demons. So Tvashta, his father, performs a yagna. And as we read that in the yagna, this is the importance of chanting the Vedic mantras accurately. He chanted the mantra Indra Shatro Vibhar Dasva. And he was supposed to chant it short, but he chanted it long. And because of this small difference of chanting it short to long, the mantra became opposite. Tvashta, when he chanted the mantra Indra Shatro Vibhar Dasva, Indra Shatro means the Shatru of Indra Vibhar Dasva may increase. So from the yagna a personality would be born who would be a Shatru of Indra, who would be the enemy of Indra. But because he chanted it long instead of chanting it short, the meaning became opposite. The meaning became Indra will become the Shatru of that personality. So now somebody asked me what's the difference whether he becomes the Shatru of him or Indra becomes the Shatru of him, what is the difference? They did not understand this. Quite a reasonable question. So it is like this: Personality and Indra. If this personality Tvashta wanted to be the enemy of Indra, then he will kill him because he is the enemy. So the personality was supposed to be born as enemy of Indra means he would kill Indra because he is the enemy. But now what happened? Indra became his enemy. So now because Indra has become his enemy, Indra will kill him. So you see how the meaning has changed. Instead of he killing Indra, he becoming so powerful that he would kill Indra, Indra got all the power by that Yagna and Indra finally killed him, Vritrasura. That's why Vritrasura was such a powerful demon. It is said that when Vritrasura appeared he was so fearful and so huge and gigantic that the demigods felt that the entire creation would be destroyed. Not just the universe, the entire creation. But Indra managed to kill him because the Yagna was performed like that. So Vritrasura has appeared. So now Indra and all the devatas are seeing this personality and they have no clue from where he has appeared and how he has appeared and they all become very very afraid and now they have taken shelter of the Supreme Personality of Godhead for protection. So this is the Mantra. So in this shloka this is the prayer of Indra to the Supreme Personality of Godhead Narayana. They are offering prayers seeking protection, seeking shelter from Lord Narayana. So here in this prayer we read this prayer how Krishna is the cause of all causes. He is the cause of Purusha. He is the cause of Prakriti. Purusha is the superior living entity, the spirit soul and the ultimate paramam Purusha is Krishna and Prakriti is this material manifestation. So all that we see in this material world is a combination of Purusha and Prakriti because we are also small Purushas. So the origin of Purusha and Prakriti is the Supreme Lord. Like that the prayer starts off and then Indra is praying to the Lord. So how do you begin a prayer? You start glorifying the Supreme Lord. So Indra is glorifying the Supreme Personality of Godhead Lord Narayana.

So in this chapter, Appearance of Demon Vritrasura, in just a few verses before, we saw how the demon Vritrasura appeared and under what conditions he appeared. Indra and all the devatas have lost their kingdom. So they are praying. They first, we know the whole story, that how they got Vishwarupa as their priest to help them and win back their kingdom. And then Vishwarupa was sikandhu. He was secretly offering the ahutis in the sacrificial fire. He was offering oblations to please the devatas, to please the Supreme Lord on behalf of the devatas and also on behalf of the demons. So Indra becomes angry and in a fit of anger, he beheads Vishwarupa, kills him. And then Vishwarupa's father, Tvashta, becomes very angry. And then Tvashta starts a sacrifice where he intended to produce, to generate a personality who will be the demon of Indra and will kill Indra. But the reverse effect happens because he chanted the mantra long instead of chanting the mantra short. So instead of, because of that mistake, the personality arose, a fearful demon who was supposed to be the enemy of Indra, but because the mantra was chanted wrong, Indra becomes his enemy. And so Indra, we will see later in the next chapter how Indra will kill him. So when this demon Vritrasura appeared, he was very, very powerful, very fearful, very vast, very ghastly. It was like appearing as if the whole universe, the whole creation will come to an end. And so all the devatas, they have no other option now but to seek shelter at the lotus feet of the Supreme Personality of God. They are offering prayers to the Supreme Personality of Godhead. So they have just finished offering their prayers and at this point of time, a wonderful thing has happened. The Supreme Personality of God personally appears. It's no ordinary thing. The Lord has appeared in His full form. Actually this chapter is called Appearance of Demon Vritrasura and there is also the Appearance of the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Hari and Narayan.

### The Urgency of Bhakti in a Godless World | Sri Vasudev Keshav Dasa | Sri Gaura Mandala Parikrama
**Speaker:** HG Vasudev Keshav Dasa

#### duty, death, devotional service
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/3CpLo1CgMbM?t=0
**Verse References:** SB 1.19.24
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The duration of life is immaterial, but the duty of a dying man is very important."
**Summary:** The speaker introduces Maharaj Pariksit's two questions about duty in life and at the time of death, explaining their significance and how the Srimad Bhagavatam addresses them, emphasizing devotional service as the ultimate duty.

Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, first canto, 19th chapter, 24th verse, appearance of Shukadev Goswami. Translation, O trustworthy brahmanas, I now ask you about my immediate duty. Please, after proper deliberation, tell me of the unalloyed duty of everyone in all circumstances and specifically of those who are just about to die. Purport, in this verse, the king has placed two questions before the learned sages. The first question is, what is the duty of everyone in all circumstances? And the second question is, what is the specific duty of one who is to die very shortly? Out of the two, the question relating to the dying man is most important, because everyone is a dying man, either very shortly or after 100 years. The duration of life is immaterial, but the duty of a dying man is very important. Maharaj Pariksit placed these two questions before Shukadev Goswami also on his arrival. And practically the whole of Srimad Bhagavatam, beginning from the second canto up to the last 12th canto, deals with these two questions. The conclusion arrived at thereof is that, devotional service of Lord Srikrishna, as it is confirmed by Lord himself in the last phases of the Bhagavad Gita, is the last word in relation to everyone's permanent duty in life. Maharaj Pariksit was already aware of this fact, but he wanted the great sages assembled there to unanimously give their verdict on his conviction, so that he might be able to go on with his confirmed duty without controversy.

So Prabhupada writes, Who is not a dying man? Everyone is a dying man. We cannot say, generally people think dying means old age. But no, we cannot be so sure when death will come. Death may come any moment. There is no guarantee. And in that way, Prabhupada says, everyone is a dying man. There was one of my neighbors, we stayed in Calcutta for about 20 years. And one Mr. Mittal Ji, we shared the same floor. We were next door neighbors. We used to spend time there. They used to spend time there. I knew them very well. So just not long time ago, but very recently I got a news about him that he passed away. It was very shocking how he passed away. He was a very hale and healthy man, very nice person, very gentle. And he had built a new house and he was supposed to be doing Griha Pravesha. There was so much of excitement and happiness in the entire family. He has three children and the pujas were supposed to begin. And he was supposed to go, the Pandit Ji told him that can you please go and bring some puja items for the puja. Something was missing or something like that. So he went to bring some puja items from the market and then family members are waiting for him to come back. And he is not returning. And then after a while it was a matter of concern what happened. And then somehow they got a call after some time that he is, who is this and he is your father and he is on the road and please come. OM NAMO BHAGAVATE VASUDEVAYA Reading from Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 1, Chapter 18, Text No. 30 SATU BRAMHARSHE RAMSHE GATHASUM URAGAM RUSHA VINIRGACCHAN DHANUSHKOTYA NIDHAYAPURA MAGATAHA Translation and purport by Sriban Grace A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Srila Prabhupada Translation While leaving, the king, being so insulted, picked up a lifeless snake with his bow and angrily placed it on the shoulder of the sage. Then he returned to his palace. The king thus treated the sage tit-for-tat. Although he was never accustomed to such silly actions, by the will of the lord, the king, while going away, found a dead snake in front of him. And he thought that the sage, who had coldly received him, thus might be coldly rewarded by being offered a garland of a dead snake. In the ordinary course of dealing, this was not very unsightly. It was unnatural. But in the case of Maharaja Pariksit dealing with a brahmana sage, this was certainly unprecedented. It so happened by the will of the lord.

So those who are extremely sinful, when they die, they don't get a next birth immediately. They will get a ghostly body. So why is a ghostly body a suffering? Because we have to understand that this body that we have consists of a subtle and a gross body. So when a person becomes a ghost, what happens is he does not have a gross body, but he has a subtle body consisting of mind, intelligence and false ego. Now, with the subtle body, there are so many desires that are stored in the subtle body. The desire to eat, taste some nice food, desire to hear some good music, desire to see some beautiful object, desire to touch some soft object etc. So now, when a person does not have a gross body, those desires, there is no way that those desires can get fulfilled. So imagine, you are chained up completely, your hands, legs, everything is tied up and you cannot see, you cannot hear, you cannot do anything. What kind of situation it will be? It will be very, very torturous situation. So when a person becomes a ghost, that's what happens with him. All his desires are there, but he does not have a gross body through which he can fulfill those desires. So it is a very distressful condition. Nobody wants to be in that condition.

Afterwards, again you are back to the business of seeking happiness. Because your actual position in material existence is to be always in a miserable condition, to be always unhappy, to be always distressed. That is our factual position in the material world. But under the influence of illusion and due to the influence of the gunas, effect of the gunas, we think sometimes we are happy, sometimes we are unhappy, and sometimes there is a neutral state where we are not exactly unhappy, but we are seeking happiness. Among the three, Brahma is actually a Jeeva, a living entity. But Brahma is immune to all the changes that take place in the universe during the life span of Brahma himself. So he is unaffected by anything that happens. But greater than Brahma is Shiva because Shiva is not a Jeeva. Shiva is not a living entity. Brahma has to die. Shiva has no death. Shiva doesn't have a material body. That's why he doesn't have to die. Death means what? Quitting the material body is called death. Soul has no death. None of us have death. The residents of Dwarka are said to be in the mood of opulence or Aishwarya and they worship Krishna as the Supreme Lord. Krishna and Balaram came to the door and stood on Subhadra's left and right sides. Once upon a time while Lord Krishna and Balarama were living peacefully in their great city of Dwaraka there was the rare occasion of a full solar eclipse such as takes place at the end of every Kalpa or day of Brahma. By astronomical calculation people were informed about this great eclipse prior to its taking place. Therefore everyone both men and women decided to assemble at the holy place in Kurukshetra known as Samantapanjaka. After arriving in Kurukshetra the members of the Yadu dynasty took their baths ceremoniously with self-control as enjoined in the Shastras and they observed fasting for the whole period of the eclipse in order to nullify the reactions of their sinful activities. The ceremonial functions performed by the members of the Yadu dynasty externally resemble the ritualistic ceremonies performed by the Karmis. When a Karmi performs some ritualistic ceremonies ambition is self-gratification, good position, good wife, good house, good children, or good wealth. But the ambition of the members of the Yadu dynasty was different. Their ambition was to offer Krishna perpetual devotion with faith.

King Nanda accompanied by his cowherd men had loaded all their necessary paraphernalia and bullock carts and all of their Vrindavan residents had come to Kurukshetra to see their beloved sons Lord Balaram and Lord Krishna. When the cowherd men of Vrindavan arrived in Kurukshetra all the Yadu dynasty members were most pleased. As soon as they saw the residents of Vrindavan they stood up to welcome them and appeared to have regained their life. All the Yadus and Vrindavan residents had been very eager to meet each other and when they actually came forward and met they embraced one another to their heart's satisfaction and remained in embrace for a considerable time. As far as the gopis of Vrindavan were concerned from the very beginning of their lives they did not know anything beyond Krishna. Krishna and Balaram were their life and soul. The gopis were so attached to Krishna that they could not even tolerate not seeing him momentarily when their eyelids blinked and impeded their vision. They condemned Brahma the creator of the body because he foolishly made eyelids which blinked and checked their seeing Krishna. Because they had been separated from Krishna for so many years the gopis having come along with Nanda Maharaj and Mother Yashoda felt intense ecstasy upon seeing Krishna. No one can imagine how eager the gopis were to see Krishna again. As soon as Krishna became visible to them they took him inside their hearts through their eyes and embraced him to their full satisfaction. Even though they were embracing Krishna only mentally they became so ecstatic and overwhelmed with joy that for the time being

#### shyness of women, Vedic culture, respect, material vs. spiritual beauty
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/GHxEhqfE3jU?t=278
**Verse References:** SB 1.10.16
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "A sweeper woman commanded the respect of many respectable gentlemen simply by manifesting a lady's shyness."
**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on Prabhupada's explanation of shyness as a natural beauty in women that commands respect, contrasting it with the lack of respect for immodesty, and emphasizing the historical presence of this cultural value in India.

Prabhupada says, "Shyness is a particular extra-natural beauty of the fair sex, and it commands respect from the opposite sex." Women naturally have got this shyness, and it is a quality that deserves to be respected by the men. So, it is said here by Srila Prabhupada further, "This custom was observed even during the days of the Mahabharata." It is more than 5000 years ago. "Only the less intelligent persons not well-versed in the history of the world say that observance of separation of female from male is an introduction of the Mohammedan period in India." This is not correct. That the separation of female from males, some people say that it is an introduction of the Mughal or Mohammedan period in India. That is not correct. As is evident from this record in the Srimad Bhagavatam and the Mahabharata, it is very clear that even in the days 5000 years back, there was this separation of the men and women. There was no free mixing. And it is a very important point to be noted. So, Srila Prabhupada says, "This incident from the Mahabharata period proves definitely that the ladies of the palace observed strict parda, restricted association with men. And instead of coming down in the open air where Lord Krishna and others were assembled, the ladies of the palace went up on top of the palace and from there paid their respects to Lord Krishna by showers of flowers." So, they showed their respect. They maintained the distance. At the same time, the respect that was being given was very evident by their action, showering flowers upon the Lord. It is definitely stated here in this verse that the ladies were smiling there on the top of the palace, checked by shyness. Both are mentioned. Prema vrida smitekshanaha. Now, prema is out of affection and love. Vrida is glancing with shyness. So, Prabhupada particularly comments about this shyness, that this shyness is a gift of nature to the fair sex, and it enhances their beauty and prestige, even if they are of a less important family, or even if they are less attractive. It's a very important point. Women generally are more attractive than men, but in case, in some instances, women are not so attractive, but still shyness enhances their beauty, and even their prestige. So, this, Srila Prabhupada explains further, "We have practical experience of this fact." And what is that experience that Prabhupada is narrating here? "A sweeper woman commanded the respect of many respectable gentlemen simply by manifesting a lady's shyness." Prabhupada is talking of his times, say about 80 years back. The sweeper woman, who is not very, not a high class lady, but still, because of her shyness, she was commanding the respect of even big gentlemen in the society. On the other hand, Prabhupada comments, "Half naked ladies in the street do not command any respect, but a shy sweeper's wife commands respect from all." So, shyness is such an important quality for a woman.

#### illusion, material vs. spiritual beauty, detachment, Vedic wisdom
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/GHxEhqfE3jU?t=593
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The real beauty is within and the real beauty belongs to the soul, not to the body."
**Summary:** The speaker explains that material beauty is an illusion, as the body is made of temporary elements, and that true beauty lies within the spirit soul, urging listeners to not be attracted by false, external beauty.

And it is very, very important. Human civilization as conceived of by the sages of India is to help one free himself from the clutches of illusion. Everyone here in this material world, men, women of whichever class, whichever standard, are all in the clutches of maya, illusion, as conditioned souls. But, the sages are instructing us to lead a particular lifestyle to become free from these clutches of the illusory energy. The material beauty of a woman is an illusion because actually the body is made of earth, water, fire, air, etc. But because there is association of the living spark with matter, this material body appears to be beautiful. Kindly note this carefully, that a woman appears attractive only because the material body is actually in contact with the living spark, the life due to the spirit soul within the body. And Prabhupada gives an example to illustrate this. No one is attracted by an earthen doll even if it is the most perfectly prepared doll to attract the attention of others. You have seen mannequins in stores which sell, let's say, some garments. They dress up a doll of a woman very nicely. Now, everyone knows this doll is actually lifeless and nobody is attracted to such a doll. So, therefore, the dead body has no beauty because no one will accept the dead body of a so-called beautiful woman. Therefore, the conclusion is that the spirit spark is beautiful and because of the soul's beauty, one is attracted by the beauty of the outward body. So, the real beauty is within and the real beauty belongs to the soul, not to the body. Therefore, the lesson to be learnt is the Vedic wisdom forbids us to be attracted by false beauty. Don't be attracted by material beauty. Don't be attracted by external beauty.

#### restricted mixing of men and women, maya, shyness, ephemeral beauty, spiritual progress
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/GHxEhqfE3jU?t=774
**Verse References:** —

**Key Quote:** "The sages of the Vedic civilization, they say that the woman is considered to be like fire and the man is considered to be butter."
**Summary:** The speaker concludes by emphasizing the Vedic restriction on mixing of men and women to avoid being trapped by illusion, highlighting shyness as a natural check on unrestricted mixing, and reminding listeners that bodily beauty is fleeting and not the true essence of attraction.

The real beauty is within. But because we are now in the darkness of ignorance, the Vedic civilization allows very restricted mixing of men and women. This restriction is necessary so that we don't become trapped by maya. This is a trap for both men and women. It's not only for men. It's for both. So, the sages of the Vedic civilization, they say that the woman is considered to be like fire and the man is considered to be butter. Butter must melt in the association of fire. Therefore, they may be brought together only when it is necessary. Men and women are brought together only when absolutely essential. And shyness is a check to the unrestricted mixing. A woman's shyness stops this unrestricted mixing of men and women and thereby saves people from becoming trapped by the illusory presentation of maya as something external, as beautiful and attractive. The real beauty is inside, within, of the spirit, not of the body. So, don't be attracted by bodily beauty. And we all know this bodily beauty is highly flickering. It is very, very short-lived. Like somebody, even if however beautiful they are, when they don't take bath, they are not dressed very nicely, neatly, or they are completely fatigued, or they become old, they have wrinkles, or they get injury on their face, then where is the beauty? Beauty is all gone. So, this is ephemeral beauty. This is not real beauty. And to not get trapped by this ephemeral beauty or false beauty, there is restriction in mixing of men and women. And also, this restriction is automatically there when women utilize the characteristic quality of theirs called shyness, and by which the restricted, unrestricted mixing is prevented, and thereby, we don't become trapped by maya. I'll stop here. Thank you very much.

So the impersonal descriptions are very prominent in the Upanishads portions of the Vedas. Whereas, the personal aspect of the Absolute Truth, that is the Personality of Godhead, Krishna, Rama, Narsimha, Varaha, all the incarnations are more nicely described in detail in the Puranas, Itihasas, like Ramayana, entirely about Lord Rama. Mahabharata, about Krishna and many other incarnations. Bhagavatam, fully about Krishna and his incarnations. So the Puranas are describing the personal feature of the Absolute Truth. Therefore, the discussions or the descriptions in the Puranas, Itihasas, about the personal feature of the Lord are more attractive and pleasing to hear than the descriptions in the Upanishads. Everything is the property of the Supreme being: Isha vasya idam sarvam yatkincha jagattyam jagat. So therefore, no one should encroach upon the property of the Supreme Lord: tena tyaktena bunjitha maa grudakasya svidhanam. One should accept only what is kindly awarded by him. And so also becomes invisible at another scheduled time. Sunrise, sunset. Becomes visible at sunrise. And the sun becomes invisible at sunset. So this is a very good example to help us understand. Similarly, the Lord appears in this universe like the sun and again leaves our sight at another time. He exists at all times at every place. Krishna is present everywhere. And always He is present. The meaning of this verse is, Maharaj Yudhishtira, after being enlightened by what was spoken by Bhishma Deva and Lord Sri Krishna, the infallible, engaged himself in matters of perfect knowledge because all his misgivings were eradicated. Thus, he ruled over the earth and seas and was followed by his younger brothers. So this verse, Sruti Goswami is describing that just after the battle of Kurukshetra, when Yudhishtira saw that such a huge massacre had taken place, 640 million Kshatriyas were killed in that battle, it is a world war. So Yudhishtira Maharaj thought, "For me to be enthroned as the emperor, so many people had to be killed." He was very much mortified. He was aggrieved by the mass killing. So then he was enlightened by Bhishma Deva and also the Supreme Lord Krishna, and when his misgivings were all gone, then he engaged himself in matters of perfect knowledge. He properly understood what is his responsibility, how he has to rule the kingdom, how he has to guide the citizens. He ruled over the earth and the seas and was followed by his younger brothers. He had four younger brothers. All of them were righteous like him, and all of them followed his footsteps in perfectly assisting him in ruling the entire world.

#### primogeniture, religious leadership, Krishna consciousness, proprietorship
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/aEnrjFjXt6U?t=187

So Srila Prabhupada explains elaborately in this purport, "The modern English law of primogeniture, or the law of inheritance by the first born, was also prevalent in those days when Maharaj Yudhishtira ruled the earth and the seas." In those days, the king of Hastinapura, which is now part of New Delhi, was the emperor of the world, including the seas, up to the time of Maharaj Pariksit, the grandson of Maharaj Yudhishtira. There was only one king, there was one flag, there was one religion until the time of Maharaj Pariksit at least, as we have information from the records, historical records in the Puranas and the Tehasas. Maharaj Yudhishtira's younger brothers were acting as his ministers and commanders of state, and there was full cooperation between the perfectly religious brothers of the king. There was full cooperation, so there was no fight for supremacy because primarily they are devotees. They accept Krishna as the supreme lord, supreme controller, and if Yudhishtira is sitting on the throne, he is sitting as the representative of Krishna. He is ruling exactly according to the directions given in the shastras by Krishna himself, and therefore there is no question of any one person enjoying. As was mentioned in the first verse, Yudhishtira Maharaj could not have enjoyed freely with unrestricted consciousness, "Oh, this kingdom I have won, now I can enjoy all the power and the wealth and the resources, natural resources." No, that was not his mood. That is never the mood of a devotee. That is never the mood of a religious or righteous person. One should accept only what is necessary for his own subsistence, understanding that everything belongs to Krishna. So nobody can claim proprietorship over what is actually rightfully belonging to the supreme personality of Godhead, who is referred to as Isavasya in the Isha Upanishad, the first of the Upanishads. That Upanishad explains everything belongs to God, everything belongs to Krishna. So Yudhishtira Maharaj never thought, "Oh, this whole kingdom is mine, I can enjoy." No, everything belongs to Krishna. As a representative of Krishna, I should rule according to the codes of direction given in Dharmashastras by Krishna.

Nothing else can attract Krishna. So in the purport, Srila Prabhupada explains, "The devotees of the Lord are purified souls." Devotee means completely purified of all material contamination. Of course, in the beginning stage, when we begin devotional service in the neophyte stage, beginning stage, we may not be completely pure, we may be contaminated to whatever extent, but devotional service itself is purifying, itself is purifying. So we become purified as we keep on rendering devotional service according to rules and regulations, according to the principles of sadhana bhakti. But when we become completely purified, then our service comes to the level of pure devotional service. As long as there is contamination in the heart, our service is a mixed devotional service. It is not counted as pure devotional service. Nevertheless, Krishna accepts if such mixed devotional service is offered through a pure devotee, spiritual master, only then Krishna accepts. If such mixed devotional service is offered through a pure devotee, spiritual master. Mixed devotional service is never accepted by Krishna if somebody tries to do that independently. Therefore, in the beginning, we have to approach a bona fide spiritual master and render service to Krishna, begin rendering or continue to render service to Krishna through the spiritual master. Only then Krishna will accept it. Krishna accepts anything only from his pure devotees. So through the pure devotee, we can offer to Krishna some food we might have cooked. Otherwise, Krishna is not hungry or Krishna is not in need of any food. But when the pure devotee recommends that here is a sincere soul wanting to offer you some service, and Krishna very kindly accepts the seva of the neophyte devotee, even though it is mixed devotional service, he accepts it through the medium of the bona fide spiritual master who is a pure devotee.

Today's slogan is that everything is for the people and therefore the government is for the people and by the people, but to produce a new species of humanity at the present moment on the basis of God consciousness and perfection of human life, the ideology of God of godly communism, the world has to again follow in the footsteps of kings like Maharaj Yudhishtira or Parikshit Maharaj. **Summary:** This segment discusses Krishna's humility in bowing to Yudhishtira, despite being the Supreme Lord, and how He enjoys being treated with love and affection by His devotees, even as an equal or subordinate, contrasting this with the impersonal understanding of Brahman.

In this session we will be discussing from the 8th verse of the 10th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. आमंत्र्यचाभ्यनु ज्ञातः परिश्वज्याभिवाध्यतं आरुरोह रथम् कैश्चित् परिश्वक्तो अभिवाधितः The meaning of this verse is, afterwards, when the Lord asked permission to depart and the king gave it, the Lord offered his respects to Maharaj Yudhishtira by bowing down at his feet. And the king embraced him. After this, the Lord, being embraced by others and receiving their obeisances, got into his chariot. So this was described as the title of the chapter, Departure of Lord Krishna for Dwaraka from Hastinapura. So Krishna, after finishing his work of conducting the battle of Kurukshetra, and installing Maharaj Yudhishtira as the emperor of the world, he was now leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka. Now the description here is that Krishna, even though he is the supreme personality of Godhead, he conducts himself in an ideal manner, setting an example for everyone else, that how the younger ones should show respect to the elders. Krishna is, that is explained by Prabhupada in the purport, Maharaj Yudhishtira was the elder cousin of Lord Krishna. So Maharaj Yudhishtira is elder to Krishna. And therefore, while departing from him, the Lord bowed down at the king's feet. King refers to Yudhishtira. So Krishna is bowing down to Yudhishtira's feet. This is the etiquette, this is the culture. Krishna is younger to Yudhishtira, so therefore he is bowing down. And Yudhishtira, what is Yudhishtira doing? The king, that is Yudhishtira, embraced him as a younger brother. Yudhishtira embraced him. Although, the king knew perfectly well that Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead. Yudhishtira knows. At the time of Krishna's advent in this world, 5,000 years back, very few people knew Krishna to be the supreme personality of Godhead. Most of them could not recognize him. So, this is another reason why people cannot recognize that Krishna behaves as if he is one among all of us. But then Krishna also performs activities which are extraordinary, which establish his position as the supreme lord. When Krishna is playing with the cowherd boys, it looks like he is one among them. But when there is a war, there is a danger. Some demon comes to attack. Krishna effortlessly kills the demons and dispatches them. So, that killing the demons is not at all an ordinary activity. It's not possible for anyone else to do that. Or lifting the Govardhan hill, that's not possible for anyone to do. Even though he is just a seven-year-old boy, he lifted the Govardhan hill on his little left finger. So, certain activities of Krishna are extraordinary. But if somebody hears about it, they don't have the proper understanding about who is Krishna. They tend to disbelieve it, or they tend to think it is some kind of mythological story. But actually, Krishna is the supreme personality of Godhead. He has unlimited power. So, it is not at all impossible for Krishna to lift the Govardhan hill, or to kill some big demons. But, Krishna also performs activities as if he is an ordinary person. So, here it is being described how the exchange took place when he was leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka. When he was leaving Hastinapura for Dwaraka, the Lord took pleasure when some of his devotees accepted him as less important in terms of love. No one is greater than or equal to the Lord, but he takes pleasure in being treated as younger than his devotees. See, this is Krishna's transcendental pastime, that even though those who recognize him, they respect him as the supreme Lord, they offer obeisances always, under all circumstances. Everyone offers obeisances to him as the supreme Lord. But, Krishna takes pleasure when his pure devotees treat him as an equal or treat him as a subordinate. Krishna takes pleasure. So, that is the personal aspect of the Lord. The Lord is the supreme Lord, as a personality. This is the feature of a personality. That they take pleasure or they love something, then it doesn't matter whether etiquette demands something else. So, these are all transcendental pastimes of the Lord, and the impersonalist cannot enter into the supernatural role.
