#### Eternal relationship with Krishna, Sun and Sun Rays Analogy, Artificial Separation, Molecular parts of Krishna
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/5jXUlaUC-oM?t=746
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** analogy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers, Newcomers
**Key Quote:** "We are eternally related with Krishna as the sun rays are eternally related with the sun disc"
**Summary:** The speaker explains the eternal relationship between the living entities and Krishna using the analogy of the sun and its rays, emphasizing that the separation is artificial and due to the influence of material energy.

Why is this so? Prabhupada explains, "Because we are eternally related with Krishna as the sun rays are eternally related with the sun disc. The sun rays are molecular parts of the solar radiation. Thus the sun rays and the sun cannot be separated. Can you have sun rays without sun planet? No. Can you have sun planet without sun planet emanating sun rays? That is also not possible. So the sun rays and the sun planet are always together, always connected. Now there is something called a separation by the cloud, but that separation by the cloud of ourselves and the sun is temporary and artificial, and as soon as the cloud is cleared, the sun rays again display the natural effulgence in the presence of the sun. Similarly, the living entities who are molecular parts of the solar radiation, sorry, the living entities who are molecular parts of the whole spirit Krishna, are separated from the Lord by the artificial energy."

Purify one's existence, sattva. Bala, they give strength. ārogyaḥ, they promote good health. Sukhaḥ means they give happiness. And prīti vyavardhanāḥ and they give satisfaction. And further characteristics of such food, such nourishing foods are sweet, juicy, fattening and palatable. So unless food is palatable, unless food is of this characteristic, it is not in the mode of goodness. Typically, food in the mode of passion is very, very pungent, extremely spicy. Excess of spice is used or excess of salt or excess of sourness, chili, like that. And food in the mode of ignorance is completely decomposing and stale. **Summary:** The lecture begins by explaining how Lord Krishna reciprocates with different types of devotees and admirers, contrasting this with the impersonalists' view of the Absolute Truth.

In this session we will be discussing from the 21st and the 22nd verses of the 11th chapter of 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam. Bhagavam Stratra Bandhunam Pauranam Anuvartinam Yathavidhi Upasangamya Sarvesham Manam Adadhe. The meaning of this 25th chapter: Lord Krishna, the personality of Godhead, approached them and offered due honor and respect to each and every one of the friends, relatives, citizens, and all others who came to receive and welcome him. He reciprocates just as it behooves with his different types of admirers and devotees. Of course the pure devotees are of one type only, because they have no other object for service but the Lord. And therefore the Lord also reciprocates with such pure devotees just as it behooves. Namely, he is always attentive to all the matters of his pure devotees. There are others who designate him as impersonal. And so, the Lord also does not take any personal interest. He satisfies everyone in terms of one's development of spiritual consciousness. And a sample of such reciprocation is exhibited here with his different welcomers."

And he is having transcendental form, transcendental qualities, transcendental feelings, transcendental activities. Whereas the impersonalists, they refuse to even consider the scriptural description of the Absolute Truth as the Supreme Person. And they make the mistake of considering him to be one of the conditioned souls. So when he is the absolute controller, how can that energy which he absolutely controls put him in illusion? That's never possible. So therefore Srila Prabhupada says that he is neither impersonal nor an inert object unable to reciprocate feelings. And of course his devotees are situated in a proper relationship with him, person to person relationship. And he accommodates all varieties of relationships. He is unlimited personality. Just like if you take a glass of water and you keep adding salt, then this salt becomes dissolved. But if you keep adding more and more salt, a certain point of saturation comes where no more salt will dissolve in that water, in the saline solution, in the salt solution. No more it will dissolve because it is saturated. Similarly, when somebody, let us say, eats a piece of sweet, then they may take a small piece and they taste it, oh it's very nice. Let me have a little more. So they have one more piece of the sweet and then they feel even more satisfied. Then one more piece, one more piece. How many pieces can they keep eating? There is a certain point of saturation or satiation where no more they can eat and relish that sweet. In fact, it becomes nausea. That means they feel like no more even looking at that sweet. So that is the point of saturation.

There were ponds full of blue and red lotus flowers, and some of these tanks were filled with varieties of vegetables, and varieties of lilies. The whole city was full of residential homes, and streets and also the thresholds of every residential house were very clean. On both sides of every path there were bushes and at regular intervals there were large trees that shaded the avenues so that the sunshine would not bother the passer-by. In this greatly beautiful city of Dwarka, Lord Krishna the Supreme Personality of Godhead had many residential quarters. The great Kings and Princes of the world used to visit these palaces just to worship Lord Krishna. The architectural plans were made personally by Vishwakarma, the engineer of the demigods. And in the construction of the palaces of Lord Krishna, he exhibited all of his talents and ingenuity. These residential quarters numbered more than 16,000.

In this session we will be discussing from the 32nd verse and the 33rd verse of the 11th chapter of the 1st canto Srimad Bhagavatam. The 32nd verse is as follows. The meaning of this verse is, So this is spoken by Suta Goswami. He is addressing the sages of Naimisharanya headed by Shaunaka, who is described here as Bruguvarya, chief amongst the Brugus. That's addressing Shaunaka Rishi, who is the chief of the Brugus. The explanation here is, the ecstasy they experienced as soon as they saw the Lord and their natural reaction was to embrace him. So first they embraced him within the innermost recesses of their hearts, and then they embraced him visually, and then they sent their sons to embrace him, which is equal to personally embracing him. Now after all this, they tried to restrain their feelings by not shedding tears, but they could not avoid that. They inadvertently shed tears. These are tears of joy on seeing their beloved Lord returned to the past. Those tears, impassioned with his love and respect. This is a very important case for the Lord. So, how can this be fair? You know, Shaunaka and his wife were inside a palace after a long period of absence. So, Srila Prabhupada explains this in the Purport. Although due to feminine shyness, there were many hindrances to embracing the dear husband, Lord Sri Krishna. The Queens performed that act by seeing him through the eyes, by putting him in the course of their hearts. As soon as they saw the impression of the Lord within the core of their heart, these were their instincts, and by sending their sons to embrace him, still the act remained unfinished and tears rolled down their cheeks despite all endeavors to check them. So Srila Prabhupada further explains here, one indirectly embraces the husband by sending the son to embrace him because the son is developed as part of the mother's body. The embrace of the son is not exactly the embrace of husband and wife from the sexual point of view, but the embrace is satisfaction from the affectionate point of view. The embrace of the eyes is more effective in the conjugal relation and thus according to Srila Jeeva Goswami there is nothing wrong in such an exchange of feeling between husband and wife. So this is the explanation

#### transcendental position of Krishna, reciprocity with devotees, supreme position of the Lord
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/eiA74rWzdOw?t=58
**Verse References:** SB 1.11.37
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "But actually Krishna is only reciprocal."
**Summary:** This segment introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam and explains that Krishna's dealings, even those that appear ordinary, are a display of his reciprocity with his devotees while maintaining his supreme position.

In this session we will be discussing from the thirty-seventh verse of the eleventh chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam: tam ayam manyate loko yasangam api sanginam atmaupamyena manujam vyapruvanam yato abudhaha. The meaning of this verse is, the common materialistic conditioned souls speculate that the Lord is one of them. Out of their ignorance they think that the Lord is affected by matter, although he is unattached. These are words spoken by Srila Suta Goswami. He is speaking to the sages of Naimisharanya. He is describing the Lord. He is describing the transcendental position of the Supreme Lord Krishna. To a common person it may appear like Krishna is an ordinary man because his dealings look like, his dealings with his queens in Dwaraka appears like he is a henpecked husband. But actually Krishna is only reciprocal. He is reciprocating with them because they are his devotees. And he is only attracted by their devotional service. And accordingly Krishna responds with every devotee, every pure devotee. And even while reciprocating with his devotees, even though he may appear to take a subordinate position, his supreme position remains unaffected, because he is the Lord eternally, always, under all circumstances, in all times, at all places, in every situation, in his dealings with everyone.

And in this way, if we become Krishna Conscious, we can very quickly cleanse our heart and become situated on the spiritual platform, even while in this material world we can be in spiritual consciousness and thereby in the spiritual world.

#### All-pervasiveness, Consciousness, Krishna's Presence
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/oTyiL8KO0dA?t=495
**Verse References:** BG 9.4

**Summary:** The speaker elaborates on the concept of all-pervasiveness, contrasting the limited consciousness of individual souls within their bodies with Krishna's unlimited consciousness that pervades everything.

Unlimited versus limited, the difference. In the Bhagavad Gita, both the living beings and the Supreme Being are said to be all-pervading. That is the description of the Lord. The living being is described as all-pervading, the spirit soul. But, there is a difference between these two. There is a difference between these two kinds of all-pervasiveness. What's the difference? A common living being or soul can be all-pervading within his own limited body. I am present throughout my body. That's why if an ant bites my toe, immediately I come to know, or an ant bites somewhere in my forehead, I immediately come to know. Because, even though I am a very tiny spirit, even though I am a very tiny spirit soul within this body, by my consciousness, I am present everywhere. My consciousness is spread throughout my body. Your consciousness is spread throughout your body. Even Brahma's consciousness is spread throughout his body. But, what about Krishna? What about Krishna's awareness or consciousness? It is spread everywhere: in the spiritual world, in the material world, in every universe, in every planet, in every living being, in every space, in all time. No limitation. The Supreme living being is all-pervading in all space and all time. You see, all space and all time. A common living being cannot extend its influence over another common living being by its all-pervasion. Very simple example: I am within this body. By even using yogic power, I cannot extend my influence over another person's body. Not possible. But the Supreme Supersoul, the Personality of God, is unlimitedly able to exert its influence over all places and all times and over all living beings. See, Krishna enters into the heart of every living being. I have entered into this body. I am situated in this body. Krishna has entered into my body, your body. You are situated in your body. You are not in my body. I am not in your body. Krishna is in your body, my body, everyone's body, everybody.

There are three grades of devotees, namely the Mahabhagavata, Madhyama Adhikari and the Kanishtha Adhikari, three grades. The topmost is the Mahabhagavata, intermediate level of devotion is the Madhyama Adhikari, intermediate level, and Kanishtha Adhikari, the lowest level, the neophyte devotee. Now Srila Prabhupada explains this, three grades of devotees. Those who go to the temples of the Lord and offer worshipful respect to the devotees, the deity, without sufficient knowledge in the theological science, and therefore without any respect for the devotees of the Lord, are called materialistic devotees or Kanishtha Adhikari, the third grade devotees, the lowest, the third grade devotees. Prakrita Bhakta, this is Sanskrit, Prabhupada translates that in English as materialistic devotees. So their conception of God is God is only in the temple and in the form of a deity. And therefore, they don't have any respect for the devotees of the Lord. Their attitude is like, I am there, God is there, that's all. And what about the others? They are also there, God is there, between them and God, between me and God, that's all. Nothing to do with interpersonal exchange between different persons. Secondly, the devotees who have developed, the second class of devotees, the devotees who have developed a mentality of genuine service to the Lord, and who thus make friendships only with similar devotees, show favor to the neophytes and avoid the atheists, are called the second grade devotees. The second grade devotees, madhyama adhikari, intermediate level devotees, the second grade devotees, they recognize four classes of people in this world. And then, they make friendship with others who are devotees, engaged in proper devotional service. And then, they are kind, and they show favor to the neophyte devotees, the beginners. And they avoid the atheists, and the agnostics, and the materialists, hardcore materialists. They avoid them. So, four categories of treatment, for four categories of personalities.

There is a cycle that is operating in this earth planet. What is that? That all living beings subsist on food grains directly or indirectly. The vegetarians directly subsist on food grains, but the non-vegetarians they subsist on animals who subsist on food grains. So therefore directly or indirectly all living beings are dependent on food grains. And the food grains are due to rains, proper rainfall. We know that when there is excessive rain or there is scarcity of rain then there is no proper production of grains. So production of grains, sufficient quantity of grains for all creatures, humans and the animals and the other birds etc. depends on proper rainfall, because we cannot manufacture food grains in factories and industries and all kinds of scientific research. We cannot manufacture food grains. It has to be grown on the land, fertile land. And even if the land is fertile, unless there is proper rainfall, you cannot get sufficient grains production. So now the rains are dependent on yajñād bhavati parjanyo. Parjanyo means rainfall. Rainfall is dependent on proper performance of yajña. So yajña performance by the human beings ensures adequate rainfall, not too much, not too little. And if there is proper rainfall, there is plenty of grain production, and that grain production will nourish all creatures on this earth planet, human beings and the lower creatures also, everyone. And this is the arrangement of the Supreme Lord. Yajña karma samudbhavaha. Yajña means to perform prescribed duties, not self-assumed duties.

He became attracted to the she-goat and somehow or other delivered her from the well, and they were united. Thereafter, when the she-goat saw the he-goat enjoying sex with another she-goat, she became angry, abandoned the he-goat, and returned to her brahmana owner to whom she described. The brahmana became angry and cursed the he-goat to lose his sexual power. Thereupon, the he-goat begged the brahmana's pardon and was given back the power for sex. Then the he-goat enjoyed sex with the she-goat for many years, but still, he was not satisfied. If one is lusty and greedy, even the total stock of gold in the entire world cannot be sold. The he-goat cannot satisfy one's lusty desires.

The shastra therefore advises that by intelligence one renounces the life of enjoyment. So, now those who are not sufficiently intelligent, they cannot give up sense enjoyment because a beautiful woman bewilders even the most learned woman. because a beautiful woman bewilders even the most learned woman. King Yayati, however, renounced worldly life and divided his property among his sons. He personally adopted the life of a mendicant, giving up all attraction to material enjoyment, and engaged himself fully in devotional service to the Lord. Thus he attained perfection. So, this is the history of Yayati described in the Bhagavatam. This Yayati, even while he was ruling, he performed many sacrifices and ensured the prosperity for everyone in his kingdom, and he was also engaged in very many pious activities by which he gave a lot of charity. The Lord says in Bhagavad Gita, yajñārthāt karmano anyatra loko yam karma-bandhanah. In the third chapter, ninth verse, Krishna says this, that one must perform sacrifices recommended in the scriptures in order to get rid of commitments of all unauthorized work or even unintentional crimes which we are apt to commit. Therefore, if one performs the recommended sacrifices, then they are freed from sinful reactions. And those who do not do so, those who do not perform sacrifices, but work for self-interest or sense gratification, such people have to undergo all tribulations accrued from committed sins. The laws of nature are very subtle and they are working perfectly and there is an enforcing authority, material nature itself being directed by the Supreme Lord Krishna. Mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ śūyateśaccharācaram. Therefore, the main purpose of performing sacrifices is to satisfy the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Hari. The process of performing sacrifices may be different in terms of different times, places and persons. Kāla, Deśa and Pātra. These are Sanskrit words: Time, place and person. But the aim of such sacrifices is one and the same at all times and in all circumstances, namely, satisfaction of the Supreme Lord Hari. Only one aim of performing sacrifices as given in the scriptures, simply to satisfy the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Hari. That is the way of pious life and that is the way of peace and prosperity in the world at large. So, by performing sacrifice for the pleasure of the Supreme Lord Hari, we not only are engaged in pious activity but we are also able to attain peace and prosperity by such performance sacrifices.

Four kinds of priests are required for performing a Vedic sacrifice. Such sacrifices were conducted from the birth of Brahma, the first living creature, and were carried on till the reign of Maharaja Yudhishthira. #### Maharaj Yudhishthira, Ramachandra, Praja, ideal king
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/CgoBer_VitE?t=246
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The king represents all living beings."
**Summary:** The speaker uses the examples of Maharaj Yudhishthira and Ramachandra as ideal kings and explains the meaning of the word 'Praja' to encompass all living beings, not just humans.

So it is confirmed herein by the example of Maharaj Yudhishtira. Ramachandra was the ideal king, and all other kings or emperors in India controlled the destiny of the world for the prosperity of every living being who took birth on the earth. You see, Ramaraja is important because Lord Ramachandra ruled in such a way that there was prosperity for every living being. And Srila Prabhupada now particularly explains the word Praja. Herein, the word Praja is significant. The etymological import of the word is that which is born, Praja, that which is born. #### Vidura's birth, Curse of Yamaraj, Lineage of Dhritarashtra and Pandu
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Gz918Ho68hY?t=76
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** story
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Vidura, born in the womb of a Shudra woman, was forbidden even to be a party of royal heritage, along with his brothers Dhritarashtra and Pandu."
**Summary:** This segment explains the story of Vidura's birth as the son of a maidservant, his relationship to Dhritarashtra and Pandu, and his resulting lack of inheritance rights.

The meaning of this verse is, as long as Vitura played the part of a Shudra, being cursed by Manduka Muni, Arhyama officiated at the post of Yamaraj to punish those who committed sinful acts. So in the Purport, Shila Prabhupada explains, already it has been told that Vitura was actually Yamaraj. Yamaraj was a Shudra. Yamaraj was cursed due to a small mistake, a slight mistake he did, in carrying out his official responsibility. And he was cursed by Manduka Muni. And therefore, he was born as Vitura in the womb of a Shudra woman. But actually, Prabhupada explains, the real reason why it was actually a higher arrangement by the Supreme Lord, that Yamaraj actually was cursed to take birth like that. So the hidden meaning of this particular incident is very nicely explained by Prabhupada in the Purport. So Shila Prabhupada says, Vitura, born in the womb of a Shudra woman, was forbidden even to be a party of royal heritage, along with his brothers Dhritarashtra and Pandu. If I may refresh your memory about who is Vitura, in terms of his relationship with Dhritarashtra and Pandu, all the three are sons of Vichitravirya, but they are posthumous children. They were born after Vichitravirya's death. And how were they born after Vichitravirya's death? This is called Deva-rena-suton-patti. That means, if a person is unable to conceive children, whatever may be the reason, why such a person, such a person is unable to conceive a child. The emperor of the world, he has to have sons who can succeed him. Qualified, capable, trained up sons. But Vichitravirya died untimely. So then there was nobody to ascend the throne. So then the mother of Vichitravirya, Satyavati, the wife of Shantanu, Vichitravirya's father, he, sorry, Satyavati, she called Vyasadeva and asked for a solution to this problem. So Vyasadeva agreed to impregnate the wives of Vichitravirya, Ampika and Ambalika, two queens. But it so happened that Vyasadeva, even though Vyasadeva was in perfect consciousness, but because he was undergoing severe austerities before he came to impregnate these wives of his brother, Deva and Sutrapati, means conceiving a child by the brother in the womb of one's own wife. So Vyasadeva was the son of Satyavati before her marriage with Shantanu. So Vyasadeva was called upon to impregnate these two queens so that they'll be good progeny for later on occupying the throne. So Dhritarashtra and Pandu were conceived by the two queens, but both of them were not conceived properly. So therefore, in order to conceive a third child, and one of the queens was asked to conceive a third child, but she, instead of conceiving one more child, she asked her maid to go in her place to conceive a child. And that royal maid actually was in very proper consciousness, and therefore, Vyasadeva conceived in that womb of the maiden, a maid servant, Yamaraj, who was cursed to be born as the son of a maid servant. So that was Vidura. So Vidura is actually a step-brother of Dhritarashtra and Pandu. So Dhritarashtra and Pandu were the two sons conceived in the queen. Even though they are conceived by Vyasadeva, they are considered sons of Vichitramirya. All the three are considered sons of Vichitramirya. But the son of the maid servant doesn't have the same position in terms of inheritance like the sons of the queen. So Dhritarashtra and Pandu inherited whatever the royal opulence, but entitled to inherit, but Vidura, as the son of a maid servant, was not entitled for that. So therefore, Srila Prabhupada is saying, Vidura, born in the womb of a Shudra woman, was forbidden even to be a party of royal heritage along with his brothers, Dhritarashtra and Pandu.

**Key Quote:** "Anyone who is conversant in the transcendental knowledge or the science of Godhead, be he a Brahmana or a Shudra...he is a Brahman."
**Summary:** This segment addresses the question of how Vidura, born a Shudra, could instruct learned Kshatriyas, explaining that spiritual qualification and transcendental knowledge are more important than birth.

So the question is being raised, how could Vidura occupy the post of a preacher to instruct such learned kings and Kshatriyas as Dhritarashtra and Maharaj Yudhishtira? If he is the son of a maid servant and he doesn't even have any inheritance, what is his authority to instruct and preach such learned Kshatriyas as Dhritarashtra and Maharaj Yudhishtira? So Srila Prabhupada gives the answer. The first answer is that even though it is accepted that Vidura was a Shudra by birth, because he renounced the word for spiritual enlightenment, by the authority of Rishi Maitreya, and was thoroughly educated by him in transcendental knowledge, he was quite competent to occupy the post of an Acharya, spiritual preceptor. So always the scriptures say, irrespective of birth, if somebody is trained up and has got the qualities of a Brahmana or a Kshatriya or even a Vaisya, even though he may be born in a Shudra family or a Shudra woman, still he is accepted as a Brahmana, Kshatriya or Vaisya according to qualification, training, the qualities he displays, etc. So Vidura was actually Yamaraja himself and even though he was born in the womb of a Shudra woman, he had all the good qualities because of which he was in a position to renounce and seek spiritual enlightenment by Maitreya Rishi and he was also thoroughly educated by Maitreya Rishi in transcendental knowledge. Therefore he was competent to occupy the post of an Acharya or a spiritual preceptor. Now Srila Prabhupada percourses Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu. According to Shri Chaitanya Mahaprabhu, anyone who is conversant in the transcendental knowledge or the science of Godhead, be he a Brahmana or a Shudra, a householder or a Sannyasi, kiba vipra kiba nyasi, shudra kenanaya, he Krishna tattva veta, he is a Brahman. If a person is born as a Shudra or if he is a Brahmana or in terms of ashrama, in terms of varana, whether he is a Brahmana or a Shudra doesn't matter. In terms of ashrama, whether he is a householder or a Sannyasi doesn't matter. As long as he is conversant with transcendental knowledge or the science of Krishna consciousness, he is a Brahmana. In terms of Akshara, he is a Brahmana of Krishna consciousness, he is eligible to become a spiritual master.

#### Yamaraj's Incarnation, Mahajana, Authority on Dharma
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Gz918Ho68hY?t=752
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "The second part of the answer is Vidura was not actually a Shudra. He was to play the part of a so-called Shudra."
**Summary:** This segment provides the second part of the answer, explaining that Vidura was actually the incarnation of Yamaraj, one of the twelve Mahajanas, and therefore an authority on Dharma.

That's the first part of the answer. Next is the other part of the reply for that question that was raised. How is he competent to instruct somebody like the Dhrashtra or Maharaja Yudhishthira? The second part of the answer is Vidura was not actually a Shudra. He was to play the part of a so-called Shudra for one hundred years being cursed by Manduka Muni. He was the incarnation of Yamaraj. And who is Yamaraj? Yamaraj is one of the twelve Mahajanas. Mahajanas means they are the authorities on Dharma. In the whole universe there are twelve Mahajanas. So Yamaraj is one of the twelve Mahajanas on the level with such exalted personalities as the other Mahajanas, Brahma, Narada, Shiva, Kapila, Bhishma, Prahlada, etc. So all these Mahajanas are the most exalted personalities in the whole universe. They are authorities on Dharma. So being a Mahajana, it is the duty of Yamaraj to preach the cult of devotion to the people of the world, as Narada, Brahma and other Mahajanas do. All the Mahajanas are first-class Mahabhagavatas, top-class Vaishnavas. And they preach the science of Krishna Consciousness to everyone. They are the most competent preachers of Krishna Consciousness. So, Prabhupada explains further. But Yamaraj is always busy in his platonic kingdom, punishing the doers of sinful acts. Yamaraj has got a duty. Even though he is a Mahajana, he is qualified, but he has got this duty of punishing the wrongdoers. So, he generally doesn't have much time to take leave from his responsible office of punishing the wrongdoers.

#### Krishna Leela, Pure Devotee, Transcendental Position
**Timestamp:** https://youtu.be/Gz918Ho68hY?t=885
**Verse References:** —
**Content Type:** philosophy
**Audience:** Full-time devotees, Congregation / volunteers
**Key Quote:** "Such a devotee is never a Shudra, or a Brahmana, or a householder, or a sannyasi. He is transcendental to all divisions of varna and ashrama."
**Summary:** This segment concludes by stating that Yamaraj took birth as Vidura to participate in Krishna Leela and that as a pure devotee, he is transcendental to all social divisions, making him qualified to preach to anyone.

Therefore, Yamaraj wanted to preach the glories of the Lord. By the will of the Lord, he was cursed to be born as a son of a Shudra. But he took birth at a time when Krishna had appeared as an incarnation. So, he participated in Krishna Leela. And also, he is an exalted devotee. Even though he is cursed, his consciousness doesn't become affected by the birth, because his activities are always those of a devotee in any body, in any situation, in any position. He is always a pure devotee, Mahabhagavata, fixed up in his position as a pure devotee. So, such a devotee is never a Shudra, or a Brahmana, or a householder, or a sannyasi. He is transcendental to all divisions of varna and ashrama. So, therefore, he is the most authorized and competent and most appropriate person to preach to anyone in the whole universe what to speak of preaching to Dhritarashtra. So, this is the explanation given. We should always understand him, Vidura, to be greater than the purest Brahmana because he is a pure devotee. He is also a Mahajan. Hare Krishna. I will stop here.
